{{About| the global economic downturn during the early 21st century|background on financial market events dating from 2007|Financial crisis of 2007–2008}} {{distinguish|Great Depression}} {{short description|Early 21st-century global economic decline}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}} [[File:GDP Real Growth in 2009.svg|thumb|upright=1.7|World map showing [[List of countries by GDP (real) growth rate|real GDP growth rates]] for 2009 (countries in brown were in recession.)]] The '''Great Recession''' was a period of general economic decline observed in world markets during the late 2000s and early 2010s. The scale and timing of the recession varied from country to country.{{cite web |title = World Economic Situation and Prospects 2013 |url = https://www.un.org/en/development/desa/policy/wesp/index.shtml |publisher = Development Policy and Analysis Division of the UN secretariat |accessdate = December 19, 2012 }}{{cite book |title = World Economic Situation and Prospects 2013 |publisher = United Nations |isbn = 978-9211091663 |page = 200 |author = United Nations |edition = 1st |type = trade paperback |date = January 15, 2013 |quote = The global economy continues to struggle with post-crisis adjustments }} The [[International Monetary Fund]] concluded that the overall impact was the most severe since the [[Great Depression]] in the 1930s. The Great Recession stemmed from collapse of the United States real-estate market, in relation to the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|financial crisis of 2007 to 2008]] and U.S. [[subprime mortgage crisis]] of 2007 to 2009, though policies of other nations contributed also. According to the U.S. [[National Bureau of Economic Research]] (the official arbiter of U.S. recessions) the US recession began in December 2007 and ended in June 2009, thus extending over 19 months.[https://www.nber.org/cycles/ US Business Cycle Expansions and Contractions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080925210636/https://www.nber.org/cycles/ |date=September 25, 2008 }}, NBER, accessed August 9, 2012. The Great Recession resulted in the scarcity of valuable assets in the market economy and the collapse of the financial sector (banks) in the world economy. Some banks were bailed out by the U.S. government.http://economics.mit.edu/files/1801{{cite web|url=http://slideplayer.com/slide/6075380/|title=The Macroeconomics of Asset Shortages - ppt video online download|website=slideplayer.com|accessdate=March 14, 2018}} The recession was not felt equally around the world. Whereas most of the world's developed economies, particularly in North America and Europe, fell into a definitive recession, many of the newer developed economies suffered far less impact, particularly [[China]] and [[India]], whose economies grew substantially during this period. ==Terminology== Two [[word sense|senses]] of the word "recession" exist: one sense referring broadly to "a period of reduced economic activity"{{Citation |author = Merriam-Webster |title = headword "recession" |work = Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary online |url = http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/recession |postscript = . }} and ongoing hardship; and the more precise sense used in [[economics]], which is [[operational definition|defined operationally]], referring specifically to the [[Inflection point|contraction phase]] of a [[business cycle]], with two or more consecutive quarters of [[GDP]] contraction. Under the academic definition, the recession ended in the United States in June or July 2009.[[Daniel Gross]], [http://www.newsweek.com/id/206631?from=rss The Recession Is... Over?], ''[[Newsweek]]'', July 14, 2009. * {{Cite news |url = http://online.barrons.com/article/SB50001424052970203983104575367471896032724.html?mod=googlenews_barrons |title = It's Dippy to Fret About a Double-Dip Recession |author = Mark Hulbert |date = July 15, 2010 }}V.I. Keilis-Borok et al., [http://www.jprr.org/index.php/jprr/article/view/106 Pattern of Macroeconomic Indicators Preceding the End of an American Economic Recession.] Journal of Pattern Recognition Research, JPRR Vol.3 (1) 2008.{{cite web |url = http://www.bendbulletin.com/article/20110629/NEWS0107/106290353/ |title = Consumer confidence falls to 7-month low | | The Bulletin |publisher = Bendbulletin.com |date = June 29, 2011 |accessdate = August 17, 2013 }}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/22/us/22poll.html|title=Nation's Mood at Lowest Level in Two Years, Poll Shows|date=April 21, 2011|work=The New York Times|last2=Thee-Brenan|first2=Megan|first1=Jim|last1=Rutenberg}}{{cite web |last = Zuckerman |first = Mortimer B. |url = https://www.usnews.com/opinion/mzuckerman/articles/2011/04/26/the-national-debt-crisis-is-an-existential-threat |title = The National Debt Crisis Is an Existential Threat |publisher = Usnews.com |date = April 26, 2011 |accessdate = August 17, 2013 }}{{cite web |author = Yoshie Furuhashi |url = http://mrzine.monthlyreview.org/2011/baker260411.html |title = Dean Baker, "Further House Price Declines in the United States" |publisher = Mrzine.monthlyreview.org |date = April 26, 2011 |accessdate = August 17, 2013 }}{{Cite news |url = https://blogs.forbes.com/brianwingfield/2010/09/20/the-end-of-the-great-recession-hardly/? |title = The End Of The Great Recession? Hardly |first = Brian |last = Wingfield |date = September 20, 2010 |work = Forbes }}{{Cite news |url = https://www.forbes.com/2010/09/20/briefing-markets-recession-over-stocks-rally.html |title = Street Rallies Around Official Recession End |first = Steve |last = Evans-Schaefer |date = September 20, 2010 |work = Forbes}} [[Robert Kuttner]] argues, “’The Great Recession,’ is a misnomer. We should stop using it. Recessions are mild dips in the business cycle that are either self-correcting or soon cured by modest fiscal or monetary stimulus. Because of the continuing deflationary trap, it would be more accurate to call this decade's stagnant economy The Lesser Depression or The Great Deflation."Kuttner, Robert. ''Debtors’ Prison: The Politics of Austerity Versus Possibility''. New York: Vintage Books, 2013, 40. ==Overview== {{Great Recession sidebar}} The Great Recession met the [[International Monetary Fund|IMF]] criteria for being a [[global recession]] only in the single calendar year 2009.{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/economics/2009/04/22/whats-a-global-recession/|title=What's a Global Recession?|last=Davis|first=Bob|date=April 22, 2009|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=September 17, 2013}}{{cite web |url = http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2009/01/pdf/text.pdf |title = World Economic Outlook — April 2009: Crisis and Recovery |format = PDF |work = Box 1.1 (page 11-14) |publisher = IMF |date = April 24, 2009 |accessdate = September 17, 2013 }} That IMF definition requires a ''decline in annual real [[Gross world product|world GDP]] per{{nbhyph}}capita ''. Despite the fact that quarterly data are being used as [[recession]] definition criteria by all [[G-20 major economies|G20 members]], representing 85% of the [[Gross world product|world GDP]],{{cite web|url = https://g20.org/about-g20/g20-members/|title = G20 Members|publisher = G20.org|accessdate = January 15, 2014|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150210155549/https://g20.org/about-g20/g20-members/|archivedate = February 10, 2015|df = }} the International Monetary Fund (IMF) has decided—in the absence of a complete data set—not to declare/measure global recessions according to quarterly GDP data. The ''seasonally adjusted [[Purchasing power parity|PPP]]{{nbhyph}}weighted real GDP'' for the G20{{nbhyph}}zone, however, is a good indicator for the world GDP, and it was measured to have suffered a direct [[quarter on quarter]] decline during the three quarters from Q3{{nbhyph}}2008 until Q1{{nbhyph}}2009, which more accurately mark when the recession took place at the global level. According to the U.S. [[National Bureau of Economic Research]] (the official arbiter of U.S. recessions) the recession began in December 2007 and ended in June 2009, and thus extended over eighteen months.{{cite news |url = https://blogs.wsj.com/economics/2008/12/01/nber-makes-it-official-recession-started-in-december-2007/ |work = The Wall Street Journal |title = NBER Makes It Official: Recession Started in December 2007 |date = December 1, 2008 }} The years leading up to the crisis were characterized by an exorbitant rise in asset prices and associated boom in economic demand.{{Cite news |url = https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/jun/03/commodities |title = Oil prices: George Soros warns that speculators could trigger stock market crash |last = Wearden |first = Graeme |date = June 3, 2008 |publisher = The Guardian |accessdate = April 10, 2009 |location = London }} Further, the U.S. [[shadow banking system]] (i.e., non-depository financial institutions such as investment banks) had grown to rival the depository system yet was not subject to the same regulatory oversight, making it vulnerable to a [[bank run]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/24/business/economy/24panel.html|title=Greenspan Concedes Error on Regulation|last=Andrews|first=Edmund L.|date=October 24, 2008|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=April 18, 2009}} US mortgage-backed [[securities]], which had risks that were hard to assess, were marketed around the world, as they offered higher yields than U.S. government bonds. Many of these securities were backed by subprime mortgages, which collapsed in value when the U.S. housing bubble burst during 2006 and homeowners began to default on their mortgage payments in large numbers starting in 2007.{{Cite news |url = https://www.forbes.com/2009/01/14/global-recession-2009-oped-cx_nr_0115roubini.html |title = A Global Breakdown Of The Recession In 2009 |author = [[Nouriel Roubini]] |date = January 15, 2009 |work = Forbes }} The emergence of [[subprime lending|sub-prime loan]] losses in 2007 began the crisis and exposed other risky loans and over-inflated asset prices. With loan losses mounting and the fall of [[Lehman Brothers]] on September 15, 2008, a major panic broke out on the inter-bank loan market. There was the equivalent of a bank run on the [[shadow banking system]], resulting in many large and well established [[investment bank|investment]] and [[commercial bank|commercial]] banks in the United States and [[Europe]] suffering huge losses and even facing bankruptcy, resulting in massive public financial assistance (government bailouts).{{cite web |url = http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2014/jul/10/geithner-does-he-pass-test/ |title = NYT-Paul Krugman-Geithner: Does He Pass The Test? |publisher = Nybooks.com |date = July 10, 2014 |accessdate = August 23, 2014 }} The global recession that followed resulted in a sharp drop in [[international trade]], rising [[unemployment]] and slumping commodity prices.{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2008/12/01/news/economy/recession/index.htm?postversion=2008120112|title=It's official: Recession since Dec '07|last=Isidore|first=Chris|date=December 1, 2008|publisher=CNN Money|accessdate=April 10, 2009}} Several economists predicted that recovery might not appear until 2011 and that the recession would be the worst since the [[Great Depression]] of the 1930s.[http://www.mcclatchydc.com/251/story/60822.html Congressional Budget Office compares downturn to Great Depression] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303075017/http://www.mcclatchydc.com/251/story/60822.html |date=March 3, 2009 }}. By David Lightman. ''McClatchy Washington Bureau.'' January 27, 2009.{{Cite news |url = https://www.theguardian.com/business/2009/jan/26/road-ruin-recession-individuals-economy |title = Twenty-five People at the Heart of the Meltdown |last = Finch |first = Julia |date = January 26, 2009 |publisher = The Guardian |accessdate = April 10, 2009 |location = London }} Economist [[Paul Krugman]] once commented on this as seemingly the beginning of "a second Great Depression".{{Cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/05/opinion/05krugman.html |last = Krugman |first = Paul |date = January 4, 2009 |title = Fighting Off Depression |publisher = The New York Times. }} Governments and central banks responded with [[Fiscal policy|fiscal]] and [[monetary policy|monetary policies]] to stimulate national economies and reduce financial system risks. The recession has renewed interest in [[2008–09 Keynesian resurgence|Keynesian economic ideas]] on how to combat recessionary conditions. Economists advise that the stimulus should be withdrawn as soon as the economies recover enough to "chart a path to sustainable growth".{{cite web |url = http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2009/01/pdf/c1.pdf |title = IMF World Economic Outlook, April 2009: "Exit strategies will be needed to transition fiscal and monetary policies from extraordinary short-term support to sustainable medium-term frameworks." (p.38) |format = PDF |date = |accessdate = January 21, 2010 }}{{Cite news |url = https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aMK3Z_HHbYM8 |title = Olivier Blanchard, the chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, "is advising officials around the world to keep economic stimulus programs in place no longer than necessary to chart a path to sustainable growth." |publisher = Bloomberg.com |date = May 30, 2005 |accessdate = January 21, 2010 }}{{Cite news |url = https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUKTRE57K5IV20090821?virtualBrandChannel=11611 |title = U.S deficit poses potential systemic risk: Taylor |publisher = Reuters.com |date = August 21, 2009 |accessdate = January 21, 2010 |first = Kristin |last = Cooke }} The distribution of household incomes in the United States has become more unequal during the post-2008 [[economic recovery]].{{cite news |last1 = Binyamin |first1 = Appelbaum |title = Fed Says Growth Lifts the Affluent, Leaving Behind Everyone Else |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/05/business/economy/least-affluent-families-incomes-are-declining-fed-survey-shows.html |accessdate = September 13, 2014 |work = New York Times |date = September 4, 2014 }} [[Income inequality in the United States]] has grown from 2005 to 2012 in more than 2 out of 3 metropolitan areas.{{cite news |last1 = Chokshi |first1 = Niraj |title = Income inequality seems to be rising in more than 2 in 3 metro areas |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/govbeat/wp/2014/08/11/income-inequality-seems-to-be-rising-in-more-than-2-in-3-metro-areas/ |accessdate = September 13, 2014 |work = Washington Post |date = August 11, 2014 }} Median household wealth fell 35% in the US, from $106,591 to $68,839 between 2005 and 2011.{{cite news |last1 = Kurtzleben |first1 = Danielle |title = Middle class households' wealth fell 35 percent from 2005 to 2011 |url = https://www.vox.com/2014/8/23/6057467/middle-class-households-wealth-fell-35-percent-from-2005-to-2011 |accessdate = September 13, 2014 |work = Vox.com |date = August 23, 2014 }} ==Causes== {{main|Causes of the Great Recession}} [[File:The Great Asset Bubble.svg|thumb|upright=1.15|The great asset bubble:{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/dan-roberts-on-business-blog/interactive/2009/jan/29/financial-pyramid|title=Global recession – where did all the money go?|last=Allen|first=Paddy|date=January 29, 2009|publisher=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=April 10, 2009}}
'''1.''' Central banks' gold reserves: $0.845 trillion.
'''2.''' M0 (paper money): $3.9 trillion.
'''3.''' Traditional (fractional reserve) banking assets: $39 trillion.
'''4.''' Shadow banking assets: $62 trillion.
'''5.''' Other assets: $290 trillion.
'''6.''' Bail-out money (early 2009): $1.9 trillion.]] {{further|Financial crisis of 2007–2008}} ===Panel reports=== The majority report provided by U.S. [[Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission]], composed of six Democratic and four Republican appointees, reported its findings in January 2011. It concluded that "the crisis was avoidable and was caused by: * Widespread failures in financial regulation, including the Federal Reserve's failure to stem the tide of toxic mortgages; * Dramatic breakdowns in corporate governance including too many financial firms acting recklessly and taking on too much risk; * An explosive mix of excessive borrowing and risk by households and Wall Street that put the financial system on a collision course with crisis; * Key policy makers ill prepared for the crisis, lacking a full understanding of the financial system they oversaw; and systemic breaches in accountability and ethics at all levels."{{cite web |url = http://fcic.law.stanford.edu/report/conclusions |title = Financial Crisis Inquiry Report-Conclusions-January 2011 |publisher = Fcic.law.stanford.edu |date = March 10, 2011 |accessdate = April 22, 2013 }} There were two Republican dissenting FCIC reports. One of them, signed by three Republican appointees, concluded that there were multiple causes. In his separate dissent to the majority and minority opinions of the FCIC, Commissioner [[Peter J. Wallison]] of the [[American Enterprise Institute]] (AEI) primarily blamed U.S. housing policy, including the actions of [[Fannie Mae|Fannie]] & [[Freddie Mac|Freddie]], for the crisis. He wrote: "When the bubble began to deflate in mid-2007, the low quality and high risk loans engendered by government policies failed in unprecedented numbers."{{cite web |url = http://fcic-static.law.stanford.edu/cdn_media/fcic-reports/fcic_final_report_wallison_dissent.pdf |title = FCIC-Final Report Dissent of Wallison-January 2011 |format = PDF |date = |accessdate = August 23, 2014 }} In its "Declaration of the Summit on Financial Markets and the World Economy," dated November 15, 2008, leaders of the [[G20 major economies|Group of 20]] cited the following causes: {{quote|During a period of strong global growth, growing capital flows, and prolonged stability earlier this decade, market participants sought higher yields without an adequate appreciation of the risks and failed to exercise proper due diligence. At the same time, weak underwriting standards, unsound risk management practices, increasingly complex and opaque financial products, and consequent excessive leverage combined to create vulnerabilities in the system. Policy-makers, regulators and supervisors, in some advanced countries, did not adequately appreciate and address the risks building up in financial markets, keep pace with financial innovation, or take into account the systemic ramifications of domestic regulatory actions.{{cite web |url = https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2008/11/20081115-1.html |title = Declaration of G20 |publisher = Whitehouse.gov |date = |accessdate = February 27, 2009 }}}} ===Narratives=== [[File:U.S. Fixed Investment as Pct GDP.png|thumb|right|upright=1.6|U.S. residential and non-residential investment fell relative to GDP during the crisis]] There are several "narratives" attempting to place the causes of the recession into context, with overlapping elements. Five such narratives include: # There was the equivalent of a [[bank run]] on the [[shadow banking system]], which includes investment banks and other non-depository financial entities. This system had grown to rival the depository system in scale yet was not subject to the same regulatory safeguards. Its failure disrupted the flow of credit to consumers and corporations.{{cite web |url = http://www.frbatlanta.org/news/CONFEREN/09fmc/gorton.pdf |title = Gary Gorton-NBER and Yale-Slapped in the Face by the Invisible Hand: Banking and the Panic of 2007-Updated May 2009 |format = PDF |date = |accessdate = August 23, 2014 }} # The U.S. economy was being driven by a housing bubble. When it burst, private residential investment (i.e., housing construction) fell by nearly four percent. GDP and consumption enabled by bubble-generated housing wealth also slowed. This created a gap in annual demand (GDP) of nearly $1 trillion. The U.S. government was unwilling to make up for this private sector shortfall.{{cite web |url = http://www.cepr.net/index.php/blogs/beat-the-press/robert-samuelson-wants-people-to-be-unemployed-the-economics-of-the-economics-of-the-great-recession |title = CEPR-Dean Baker-The Economics of the Great Recession-June 29, 2014 |publisher = Cepr.net |date = June 29, 2014 |accessdate = August 23, 2014 }}{{cite web|url=https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/07/01/learned-macroeconomic-helplessness/?module=BlogPost-Title&version=Blog+Main&contentCollection=Opinion&action=Click&pgtype=Blogs®ion=Body|title=Learned Macroeconomic Helplessness|publisher=|accessdate=March 14, 2018}} # Record levels of [[household debt]] accumulated in the decades preceding the crisis resulted in a [[balance sheet recession]] (similar to [[debt deflation]]) once housing prices began falling in 2006. Consumers began paying off debt, which reduces their consumption, slowing down the economy for an extended period while debt levels are reduced.{{cite book |last = Mian, Atif and |first = Sufi, Amir |year = 2014 |title = [[House of Debt]] |publisher = University of Chicago |isbn = 978-0-226-08194-6 }} # U.S. government policies encouraged home ownership even for those who could not afford it, contributing to lax lending standards, unsustainable housing price increases, and indebtedness.{{cite book|title=[[The Housing Boom and Bust]]|last=Sowell|first=Thomas|publisher=Basic Books|year=2009|isbn=978-0-465-01880-2|pages=57–58|authorlink=Thomas Sowell}} # Wealthy and middle-class [[flipping|house flippers]] with mid-to-good credit scores created a [[Economic bubble|speculative bubble]] in house prices, and then wrecked local housing markets and financial institutions after they defaulted on their debt en masse.{{cite web|url=https://qz.com/1064061/house-flippers-triggered-the-us-housing-market-crash-not-poor-subprime-borrowers-a-new-study-shows/|title=House flippers triggered the US housing market crash, not poor subprime borrowers|first=Gwynn|last=Guilford|publisher=|accessdate=March 14, 2018}} Underlying narratives #1-3 is a hypothesis that growing [[Income inequality in the United States|income inequality]] and [[Household income in the United States|wage stagnation]] encouraged families to increase their [[household debt]] to maintain their desired living standard, fueling the bubble. Further, this greater share of income flowing to the top increased the political power of business interests, who used that power to [[Deregulation|deregulate]] or limit regulation of the shadow banking system.{{cite web|url=http://www.american.edu/cas/economics/pdf/upload/2012-1.pdf|title=Jon Wisman-Wage Stagnation, Rising Inequality and the Crisis of 2008-Retrieved June 2015|publisher=|accessdate=March 14, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/wp/2010/wp10268.pdf|title=IMF-Inequality, Leverage and Crises-Kumhoff and Ranciere-November 2010|publisher=|accessdate=March 14, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.peri.umass.edu/fileadmin/pdf/working_papers/working_papers_251-300/WP282.pdf|title=Stockhammer-Rising Inequality as a Cause of the Present Crisis-Amherst PERI-April 2012|publisher=|accessdate=March 14, 2018}} Narrative #5 challenges the popular claim that subprime borrowers with shoddy credit caused the crisis by buying homes they couldn't afford. This narrative is supported by new research showing that the biggest growth of mortgage debt during the U.S. housing boom came from those with good credit scores in the middle and top of the credit score distribution—and that these borrowers accounted for a disproportionate share of defaults.{{cite web|url=http://mitsloan.mit.edu/newsroom/articles/rethinking-how-the-housing-crisis-happened/|title=Rethinking how the housing crisis happened|website=mitsloan.mit.edu|accessdate=March 14, 2018}} ===Trade imbalances and debt bubbles=== [[File:US Private Debt to GDP by Sector.png|thumb|upright=1.6|right|U.S. households and financial businesses significantly increased borrowing (leverage) in the years leading up to the crisis]] ''[[The Economist]]'' wrote in July 2012 that the inflow of investment dollars required to fund the U.S. trade deficit was a major cause of the housing bubble and financial crisis: "The trade deficit, less than 1% of GDP in the early 1990s, hit 6% in 2006. That deficit was financed by inflows of foreign savings, in particular from East Asia and the Middle East. Much of that money went into dodgy mortgages to buy overvalued houses, and the financial crisis was the result."{{cite news |url = http://www.economist.com/node/21558591 |title = The Economist-Points of Light-July 14, 2012 |publisher = Economist.com |date = July 14, 2012 |accessdate = April 22, 2013 }} In May 2008, NPR explained in their [[Peabody Award]] winning program "[[The Giant Pool of Money]]" that a vast inflow of savings from developing nations flowed into the mortgage market, driving the U.S. housing bubble. This pool of fixed income savings increased from around $35 trillion in 2000 to about $70 trillion by 2008. NPR explained this money came from various sources, "[b]ut the main headline is that all sorts of poor countries became kind of rich, making things like TVs and selling us oil. China, India, Abu Dhabi, Saudi Arabia made a lot of money and banked it."{{cite web |url = http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/355/transcript |title = NPR-This American Life-The Giant Pool of Money-May 2008 |publisher = Thisamericanlife.org |date = |accessdate = April 22, 2013 }} Describing the crisis in Europe, [[Paul Krugman]] wrote in February 2012 that: "What we're basically looking at, then, is a balance of payments problem, in which capital flooded south after the creation of the euro, leading to overvaluation in southern Europe."{{cite news |url = https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/02/25/european-crisis-realities/ |title = NYT-Paul Krugman-European Crisis Realities-February 2012 |publisher = Krugman.blogs.nytimes.com |date = February 25, 2012 |accessdate = April 22, 2013 }} ===Monetary policy=== Another narrative about the origin has been focused on the respective parts played by the public monetary policy (in the US notably) and by the practices of private financial institutions. In the U.S., mortgage funding was unusually decentralised, opaque, and competitive, and it is believed that competition between lenders for revenue and market share contributed to declining underwriting standards and risky lending. While Alan Greenspan's role as [[Chairman of the Federal Reserve]] has been widely discussed (the main point of controversy remains the lowering of the [[Federal funds rate]] to 1% for more than a year, which, according to [[Austrian School|Austrian theorists]], injected huge amounts of "easy" credit-based money into the financial system and created an unsustainable economic boom),{{Cite news |last = Polleit |first = Thorsten |url = https://mises.org/story/2810 |title = Manipulating the Interest Rate: a Recipe for Disaster |publisher = Mises Institute |date = December 13, 2007 |accessdate = January 4, 2009 }} there is also the argument that Greenspan's actions in the years 2002–2004 were actually motivated by the need to take the U.S. economy out of the [[early 2000s recession]] caused by the bursting of the [[dot-com bubble]]—although by doing so he did not help avert the crisis, but only postpone it.{{cite web |first = Ann |last = Pettifor |url = http://www.opendemocracy.net/article/america-s-financial-meltdown-lessons-and-prospects |title = America's financial meltdown: lessons and prospects |publisher = openDemocracy |date = September 16, 2008 |accessdate = January 4, 2009 }}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mises.org/story/1670|title=America's Unsustainable Boom|last=Karlsson|first=Stefan|date=November 8, 2004|publisher=Mises Institute|accessdate=January 4, 2009}} ===High private debt levels=== [[File:U.S. Household Debt Relative to Disposable Income and GDP.png|thumb|upright=1.15|US household debt relative to disposable income and GDP.]] [[File:Change in household debt - v1.png|thumb|upright=1.15|right|U.S. Changes in Household Debt as a percentage of GDP for 1989-2016. Homeowners paying down debt for 2009-2012 was a headwind to the recovery. Economist [[Carmen Reinhart]] explained that this behavior tends to slow recoveries from financial crises relative to typical recessions.{{cite journal |doi=10.3386/w16334 |title=After the Fall|first1=Carmen M.|last1=Reinhart|first2=Vincent R.|last2=Reinhart|date=September 2010|work=NBER Working Paper No. 16334 }}]] Another narrative focuses on high levels of private debt in the US economy. USA [[household debt]] as a percentage of annual [[disposable personal income]] was 127% at the end of 2007, versus 77% in 1990.{{cite news |url = http://www.economist.com/world/unitedstates/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12637090 |title = The End of the Affair |publisher = Economist |date = October 30, 2008 |accessdate = February 27, 2009 }}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/13/opinion/13krugman.html|title=Opinion - Block Those Economic Metaphors|first=Paul|last=Krugman|date=December 12, 2010|publisher=|accessdate=March 14, 2018|via=NYTimes.com}} Faced with increasing mortgage payments as their adjustable rate mortgage payments increased, households began to default in record numbers, rendering mortgage-backed securities worthless. High private debt levels also impact growth by making recessions deeper and the following recovery weaker.{{cite web |url = http://www.eestipank.ee/en/publication/working-papers/2011/martti-randveer-lenno-uuskula-liina-kulu-impact-private-debt-economic-growth |title = THE IMPACT OF PRIVATE DEBT ON ECONOMIC GROWTH |author1=Martti Randveer |author2=Lenno Uusküla |author3=Liina Kulu |quote = "Both theoretical and empirical evidence show that recessions are steeper in countries with high levels of private debt and/or credit booms." and "We find that a higher level of debt before a recession is correlated with smaller economic growth after the economic slowdown has finished." |publisher = Eestipank.ee |date = |accessdate = April 22, 2013 }}{{cite web |last = Bianco |first = James |url = http://www.ritholtz.com/blog/2012/06/are-u-s-debt-levels-now-manageable/ |title = Chart titled "Anyone See Deleveraging?" |publisher = Ritholtz.com |date = June 13, 2012 |accessdate = August 23, 2014 }} [[Robert Reich]] claims the amount of debt in the US economy can be traced to economic inequality, assuming that middle-class wages remained stagnant while wealth concentrated at the top, and households "pull equity from their homes and overload on debt to maintain living standards".{{cite news |url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/10/22/income-inequality-america_n_772687.html |title = How American Income Inequality Hit Levels Not Seen Since The Depression |work = huffingtonpost.com |accessdate = October 24, 2010 |first = Ryan |last = McCarthy |date = October 22, 2010 }} The IMF reported in April 2012: "Household debt soared in the years leading up to the downturn. In advanced economies, during the five years preceding 2007, the ratio of household debt to income rose by an average of 39 percentage points, to 138 percent. In Denmark, Iceland, Ireland, the Netherlands, and Norway, debt peaked at more than 200 percent of household income. A surge in household debt to historic highs also occurred in emerging economies such as Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, and Lithuania. The concurrent boom in both house prices and the stock market meant that household debt relative to assets held broadly stable, which masked households' growing exposure to a sharp fall in asset prices. When house prices declined, ushering in the global financial crisis, many households saw their wealth shrink relative to their debt, and, with less income and more unemployment, found it harder to meet mortgage payments. By the end of 2011, real house prices had fallen from their peak by about 41% in Ireland, 29% in Iceland, 23% in Spain and the United States, and 21% in Denmark. Household defaults, underwater mortgages (where the loan balance exceeds the house value), foreclosures, and fire sales are now endemic to a number of economies. Household [[deleveraging]] by paying off debts or defaulting on them has begun in some countries. It has been most pronounced in the United States, where about two-thirds of the debt reduction reflects defaults."{{cite web|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2012/01/pdf/c3.pdf|title=IMF-Report Extract Chapter 3 – April 2012|date=|format=PDF|accessdate=August 17, 2013}}{{cite web |url = http://www.mckinsey.com/insights/mgi/research/financial_markets/debt_and_deleveraging_the_global_credit_bubble_update |title = McKinsey-Debt and deleveraging: The global credit bubble and its economic consequences-Updated-July 2011 |publisher = Mckinsey.com |date = March 13, 2013 |accessdate = August 17, 2013 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130307011351/http://www.mckinsey.com/insights/mgi/research/financial_markets/debt_and_deleveraging_the_global_credit_bubble_update |archive-date = March 7, 2013 |dead-url = yes |df = mdy-all }} ===Pre-recession warnings=== The onset of the economic crisis took most people by surprise. A 2009 paper identifies twelve economists and commentators who, between 2000 and 2006, predicted a recession based on the collapse of the then-booming housing market in the United States:Dirk J Bezemer: ''"No One Saw This Coming" Understanding Financial Crisis Through Accounting Models'', available via: [http://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/15892/1/MPRA_paper_15892.pdf MPRA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906094437/http://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/15892/1/MPRA_paper_15892.pdf |date=September 6, 2015 }}, esp. p. 9 and appendix. Page 61-62 What Can Be Forecasted}} [[Steve Keen]], [[Jakob Broechner Madsen|Jakob Brøchner Madsen]], Jens Kjaer Sørensen, [[Kurt Richebächer]], [[Nouriel Roubini]], [[Peter Schiff]], and [[Robert
