The '''International Decision Support Initiative''' ('''iDSI''') is a partnership between governments, universities, and thinktanks that helps health policy makers make better decisions.<ref name=about>{{cite web |url=http://www.idsihealth.org/about-us/ |title=ABOUT US |publisher=iDSI |accessdate=May 26, 2016}}</ref><ref name=phase2/> iDSI targets [[Developing country|low- and middle-income countries]] (LMICs),<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.bmj.com/content/bmj/352/bmj.i244.full.pdf |title=Role of priority setting in implementing universal health coverage |author=Yot Teerawattananon |publisher=The BMJ|display-authors=etal}}</ref> helping them prioritize health interventions as a means toward [[universal health coverage]].<ref name=cgdev>{{cite web |url=http://www.cgdev.org/working-group/priority-setting-institutions-global-health |title=Priority-Setting Institutions for Global Health |publisher=Center for Global Development |accessdate=May 29, 2016}}</ref> iDSI launched in November 2013<ref name=about/> as the result of a 2012 [[Center for Global Development]] working group.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.impatientoptimists.org/Posts/2016/02/The-International-Decision-Support-Initiative-Is-Scaling-UpThat-Means-Better-Decisions-and-Better-Health |title=The International Decision Support Initiative Is Scaling Up—That Means Better Decisions and Better Health |author=[[Amanda Glassman]] |date=February 8, 2016 |website=Impatient Optimists |publisher=Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation}}</ref><ref name=cgdev/>
==Partnerships==
The following organizations are iDSI's core partners:<ref name=phase2/>
* [http://www.imperial.ac.uk/centre-for-health-policy/our-work/global-health-and-development-group-/ Global Health and Development Group] (GHD) * HITAP ([[Health Intervention and Technology Assessment Program]], Thailand) * [[Center for Global Development]]<ref name=cgdev/> * [[PRICELESS SA]] (Priority Cost Effective Lessons for System Strengthening, South Africa)
Other partners include [[Centre for Health Economics]] (at the [[University of York]]), [[Imperial College London]], [[Itad]], [[Johns Hopkins Berman Institute of Bioethics]], the [[London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine]], [[Meteos (nonprofit company)|Meteos]], [[The Office of Health Economics|Office of Health Economics]], the [[University of Glasgow]], and the [[University of Strathclyde]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.idsihealth.org/who-we-are/supporting-partners/ |title=Supporting Partners |publisher=iDSI |accessdate=May 26, 2016}}</ref>
==Funding==
iDSI receives funding from the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]], the [[Department for International Development|UK Department for International Development]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ohe.org/news/international-decision-support-initiative-idsi-mapping-priority-setting-health-17-low-and |title=international Decision Support Initiative (iDSI): Mapping of Priority-setting in Health in 17 Low and Middle Income Countries Across Asia, Latin America and Africa |accessdate=May 29, 2016 |date=April 22, 2015 |publisher=Office of Health Economics}}</ref> and the [[Rockefeller Foundation]].<ref name=about/><ref name=phase2/>
In December 2015, iDSI received $12.8 million in funding from the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]] for phase 2 of its operations.<ref name="phase2">{{cite web |url=http://www.idsihealth.org/blog/idsi2-launch/ |title=International Decision Support Initiative awarded US$12.8m grant from the Gates Foundation |publisher=iDSI |accessdate=May 26, 2016 |date=January 30, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gatesfoundation.org/How-We-Work/Quick-Links/Grants-Database/Grants/2015/12/OPP1134345 |title=National Institute for Health and Care Excellence |date=December 2015 |publisher=Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation}}</ref>
==Work==
iDSI has operated in China, India, Indonesia, Myanmar, the Philippines, South Africa, and Vietnam as "focus countries", but has also operated in additional countries.
Most of iDSI's work has focused on [[noncommunicable diseases]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.idsihealth.org/blog/idsi-in-action/india-2/ |title=iDSI in India |publisher=iDSI |accessdate=June 5, 2016}}</ref> [[Maternal death|maternal]] and [[Child mortality|child death]], and more general [[Priority-setting in global health|priority-setting]].
As part of their focus on [[universal health care]], iDSI has also worked on priority setting for mental health.<ref>{{cite web |author = Ryan Li |url=http://blogs.worldbank.org/health/comment/393#comment-393 |title=Thank you for raising such an |accessdate=May 29, 2016 |date=April 25, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.idsihealth.org/blog/who-we-are/people/ryan-li/ |title=Ryan Li |publisher=iDSI |accessdate=May 29, 2016}}</ref>
iDSI is one of the collaborators for [[Disease Control Priorities Project#DCP3|DCP3]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dcp-3.org/collaborators |title=Collaborators |publisher=DCP3 |accessdate=May 26, 2016}}</ref>

[[File:Voice of Turkey Interval Signal.ogg|thumb|The interval signal of [[Voice of Turkey]] as heard in 2013.]] An '''interval signal''', or '''tuning signal''', is a characteristic sound or musical phrase used in [[international broadcasting]], [[numbers stations]], and by some domestic broadcasters, played before commencement or during breaks in transmission, but most commonly between programmes in different languages. It serves several purposes: * It assists a listener to tune his or her radio to the correct frequency of the station. This is because most older and cheaper radio receivers do not have digital frequency readout. * It informs other stations that the frequency is in use. * It serves as a station identifier even if the language used in the subsequent broadcast is not one the listener understands. The practice began in Europe in the 1920s and 1930s and was carried over into [[shortwave]] broadcasts. The use of interval signals has declined with the advent of digital tuning systems, but has not vanished. Interval signals were not required on commercial channels in the USA, where jingles were used as identification. == Broadcasting services and interval signals == * {{Flagicon|UK}} [[BBC World {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}} {{dynamic list|date=April 2015}} American singer [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], throughout her career, spanning three decades, has obtained a remarkable series of statistical achievements, setting and breaking several [[world record]]s with her participation in entrepreneurial activities, of acting and her performance in the musical scene for her [[Madonna videography|videos]], [[Madonna singles discography|singles]], [[Madonna albums discography|albums]], and [[List of Madonna concert tours|tours]].
Her first appearance in the ''[[Guinness Book of World Records]]'' was in 1986 with her third studio album, ''[[True Blue (Madonna album)|True Blue]]''. Since then, she has earned multiple appearances, some 20 at least in February 2012, including her insigne record title as the [[List of best selling music artists|top-selling female recording artist of all time]]. Madonna's commerciality has achieved scrutiny studies and analysis from different point of view in the [[academia]] world or by marketers, through her [[Marketing strategy|marketing strategies]], controversies and reinvention, surpassing to others new or [[contemporary]] artists. In [[popular culture]], many international artists have been called "[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|Madonna]]", many times, by their impact and success in their respective countries or genres. Also, her presence in popular culture, has been led to create world records about Madonna. Dubbed as the most successful and most influential female artist of all time,<ref name="WMA">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldmusicawards.com/index.php/news/how-madonna-changed-world/|title=How Madonna changed the World!|date=August 17, 2013|accessdate=April 11, 2015|work=[[World Music Awards]]}}</ref><ref name="cnn2008">{{cite news|first=Stephanie|last=Busari|title=Hey Madonna, Don't Give Up the Day Job!|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/Movies/03/18/madonna.movies/?iref=mpstoryview|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=March 24, 2008|accessdate=April 11, 2015}}</ref> {{TOC limit|3}}

==== ''Billboard'' Hot 100 chart statistics ==== {{see also|List of artists by number of Billboard Hot 100 number-one singles}} {{Pie chart | thumb = right | caption = Madonna's number-one singles on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 | other = | label1 =1980s: 7 singles | value1 = 58.3 | label2 =1990s: 4 singles | value2 =33.3 | label3 =2000s: 1 single | value3 =8.4 }}
When she reached number one with "[[Music (Madonna song)|Music]]" in 2000 at Billboard Hot 100, it made Madonna the second artist to achieve number one hits on the Hot 100 in the 1980s, 1990s and 2000s.<ref name="JanetJackson">{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fxEEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA100|title=Making Her Own Kind of Music|last=Bronson|first=Fred|date=September 16, 2000|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=March 13, 2015|page=100|issn=0006-2510|volume=112|issue=38}}</ref> Also, when she released "Who's That Girl" in 1987 it became Madonna's sixth number-one single in the United States, making her the first artist to accumulate six number-one singles in the 1980s, and the first female performer to get that many number-ones as a solo act.<ref name="ach">{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6229105/madonna-song-whos-that-girl-no-1|title=Flashback Friday: Madonna's 'Who's That Girl' Hit No. 1|last=Strecker|first=Erin|date=August 8, 2014|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=March 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/24660679.html?dids=24660679:24660679&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+21%2C+1987&author=Jan+DeKnock&pub=Chicago+Tribune+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=MADONNA+SOARS+TO+TOP+OF+THE+CHARTS+FOR+THE+SIXTH+TIME&pqatl=google|title=Madonna Soars to Top of the Charts for the Sixth Time|date=August 22, 1987|author=DeKnock, Jan|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=March 13, 2015}}</ref> In 2012, with "[[Give Me All Your Luvin']]" she became the second female with highest number of ''Billboard'' Hot 100 singles by female artists, only behind [[Aretha Franklin]]. The song is her 56th appearance on the chart.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/music/bp/week-ending-feb-5-2012-songs-madonna-mj-024543065.html|title=Week Ending Feb. 5, 2012. Songs: Madonna & MJ|author=Paul Grein|date=February 8, 2012|accessdate=March 7, 2015|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]}}</ref> In 1991, with "[[Rescue Me (Madonna song)|Rescue Me]]" when it debuted at No. 15 on the March 2, 1991 Hot 100 chart, it marked the highest-ever bow for a single by a woman. Further, it was —at the time— one of only four titles to debut in the top 20.<ref name="40Biggest">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/list/499398/madonnas-40-biggest-billboard-hits|title=Madonna's 40 Biggest Billboard Hits|date=March 2, 2015|accessdate=March 7, 2015|work=Billboard|author=Keith Caulfield}}</ref> Madonna is the third oldest female to place a number one at the Billboard Hot 100. The single "Music" reached the number-one spot when Madonna was forty-two years one month old (September 2000). She holds the record with 38 singles within the Top 10, most for any artist.<ref name="40Biggest"/><ref name="recordTop10"/>

==== Dance Club Songs chart statistics ==== {{see also|List of artists who reached number one on the U.S. dance chart|List of Billboard number-one dance hits}}
She has 46 number-one songs in the chart —the most for any artist.<ref name="danceone" /><ref name="USDance42">{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/chartbeat/497029/madonna-notches-42nd-no-1-on-danceclub-play-songs|title=Madonna Notches 42nd No. 1 on Dance/Club Play Songs|author=Gary Trust|date=April 9, 2012|accessdate=March 30, 2015|work=Billboard}}</ref> Also, is the only active artist to chart continuously since 1982, spanning four decades. ''Billboard'' said: "comparing her chart champs by decade, Madonna scored nine Dance/Club Songs No. 1s in the '80s and 13 in the '90s. Since 2000, she has almost doubled her total, adding 18 No. 1s in that span".<ref name="USDance40">{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/267393/celebration-madonnas-40-most-impressive-instants|title='Celebration': Madonna's 40 Most Impressive Instants|author=Gary Trust|date=September 15, 2009|accessdate=April 1, 2015|work=Billboard}}</ref> In 2012, when she release "Girl Gone Wild", became her 42nd No. 1 on the record chart, ''Billboard'' said that she has the quickest span of back-to-back No. 1s.<ref name="USDance42"/> Also, the magazine declared that "essentially, if Madonna releases a single and it charts on Dance/Club Play Songs, it's a safe bet to assume it'll go to No. 1. Since 2000, she's placed 26 hits on the survey. Of those, all but six have gone all the way to No. 1.<ref name="ElvisandMadonna">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/chartbeat/513469/elvis-presley-madonna-the-day-the-music-died-and-was-born|title=Elvis Presley & Madonna: The Day the Music Died, and Was Born|work=Billboard|accessdate=April 10, 2015|date=August 16, 2012|author=Gary Trust}}</ref> Also, Madonna is the only artist in history to achieve seven top-ten hits from one album (''[[American Life]]'') and the only artist ever to achieve seven consecutive number-one hits on this chart twice.
"[[Give Me All Your Luvin']]" set a record chart, when it debuted at 24 in the [[Hot Dance Club Songs|Dance/Club Play Songs chart]] and rose to 9 the next week, having the fastest rising to the top 10 for a song ever<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/chartbeat/502935/weekly-chart-notes-kelly-clarkson-adele-madonna|title=Weekly Chart Notes: Kelly Clarkson, Adele, Madonna|work=Billboard|accessdate=March 12, 2015}}</ref> "Hung Up" became the most successful dance song of the [[2000s in music|2000s]] in the United States, by topping the Dance/Club Play Songs Decade-end tally and "Music" became the second most-successful dance song of decade, reaching number two on the record chart.<ref name="dance decade">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts-decade-end/dance-club-play-songs?year=2009|title=Billboard Charts – Decade-end Singles – Dance/Club Play Songs|work=Billboard|accessdate=March 12, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108112432/http://www.billboard.com/charts-decade-end/dance-club-play-songs?year=2009|archivedate=November 8, 2012}}</ref> Furthermore, "Music" was also the longest-running number one song on Dance/Club Play Songs in the 2000s, with a longevity of five weeks at number one.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2000-09-16/dance-club-play-songs|title=Dance Club Play Songs|date=September 16, 2000|accessdate=March 12, 2015|publisher=''Billboard''. Nielsen Business Media, Inc.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2000-10-14/dance-club-play-songs|title=Dance Club Play Songs|date=October 14, 2000|accessdate=March 12, 2015|publisher=''Billboard''. Nielsen Business Media, Inc.}}</ref>

==== ''Billboard'' 200 chart statistics ==== {{see also|List of Billboard 200 number-one albums}} {{Pie chart | thumb = right | caption = Madonna's number-one albums on the ''Billboard'' 200 | other = | label1 =1980s: 3 albums | value1 =37.5 | label2 =1990s: 0 album | value2 =0 | label3 =2000s: 4 albums | value3 =50 | label4 =2010s: 1 album | value4 =12.5 }}
She is the second female artist with most number ones albums, with 8, behind only [[Barbra Streisand]], who has 10 number one albums.<ref name="StreisandRecord">{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/music/bp/chart-watch-barbras-six-decade-streak-at-1-221212338.html|title=Chart Watch: Barbra's Six-Decade Streak At #1|author=Paul Grein|publisher=Yahoo!|date=September 18, 2014|accessdate=March 9, 2015}}</ref> Her [[Billboard 200#Artist milestones|other achievements]] on the record chart, tied with [[Beyoncé]] as the female artist with most consecutive number-one albums.<ref name="Beyonce">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1719282/beyonce-album-number-one-debut/|title=Beyoncé Debuts At #1, Makes Billboard History|author=James Montgomery|publisher=[[MTV]]|date=December 18, 2013|accessdate=March 9, 2015}}</ref> Also, in 1984 Madonna was the first female to sell over 5 million albums in the US in a single year with ''[[Like a Virgin (album)|Like a Virgin]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Grein|first=Paul|date=August 10, 1985|title=Hot Madonna: July Fills Her Coffers With RIAA Metal|journal=Billboard|location=New York|volume=97|issue=32|pages=7|issn=0006-2510|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6iQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA7|accessdate=February 16, 2010}}</ref> Madonna is the artist with most top 10 albums on the Billboard 200, with 21 (20 in 2012, with ''MDNA'')<ref name="ElvisandMadonna"/> [[George Strait]] places second with 17 top 10s, followed by Mariah Carey (16). Also, she is the female artist with most number-two albums on Billboard's Top 200 Albums, with six, tied with The Beatles and behind [[Frank Sinatra]]'s seven
Her albums ''The Immaculate Collection'', ''Like a Virgin'' and ''True Blue'' are among the top 100 certified albums according to the [[RIAA]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinum.php?content_selector=top-100-albums|title=RIAA: Top 100 Certified Albums|publisher=Recording Industry Association of America|accessdate=August 6, 2012}}</ref> with ''The Immaculate Collection'' and ''Like a Virgin'' becoming in one of the [[List of best-selling albums in the United States|best-selling albums in United States]] with a [[RIAA certification|diamond status]]. As of 2015, she is the eighth artist with most number-one albums. However, she has a record for the biggest second week sales drop in history in [[Nielsen SoundScan]] era with her twelfth studio album, ''MDNA''.

==== Canadian singles chart statistics ==== {{see also|List of artists who reached number one on the Canadian Hot 100|List of number-one singles in Canada}} She has a total of 25 #1 singles in Canada — the most for any artist in spanning four decades: 1980s, 1990s, 2000s and 2010s. Only two of these number one singles belong to [[Canadian Hot 100]] and the rest of [[RPM (magazine)|Canadian RPM singles chart]]. Her 2000 single "Music" was [[List of number-one singles of 2000 (Canada)|the last number one hit]] on the [[RPM (magazine)|Canadian RPM singles chart]]. Also, she has sixty-eight Top 40, fifty-nine Top 20, fifty-one Top 10 and thirty-nine Top 5 singles.<ref name="canadiancharts"> For peak chart positions for Madonna's singles on Canadian charts from 2000–present, see [[AllMusic]] and the Billboard.com link. For Peak chart positions for Madonna's singles from 1983 to 1999, on Canada's ''RPM'' Singles Chart, see the RPM link. *{{cite web|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=v2a76h62to0aart05gg0u3agj2&q1=Madonna|title=Madonna Singles Discography|work=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]|publisher=RPM Library Archives|accessdate=April 3, 2015}} *{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=madonna|chart=Billboard Canadian Hot 100}}|title=Madonna Album & Song Chart History – Billboard Canadian Hot 100|work=Billboard}} </ref> "4 Minutes" debuted at the top of the Canadian [[Contemporary Hit Radio]] chart. This marked the first time any song entered at the top of the CHR chart in [[Nielsen Broadcast Data Systems|BDS]] history.<ref name="canadian4minutes">{{cite press release|url=http://www.marketwire.com/press-release/madonna-4-minute-fever-spreads-across-the-world-victims-cant-stop-dancing-839706.htm|title='4 Minutes' is the fastest single to hit #1 in Canadian radio history|author=Press Release|date=March 26, 2008|publisher=[[Nielsen Broadcast Data Systems]]|page=2|accessdate=April 7, 2015}}</ref> With "Music and "American Pie" was the first time in Canadian chart history that an artist held the top two positions on the year-end musical charts.

==== UK Singles Chart statistics ==== {{see also|List of artists by number of UK Singles Chart number ones|List of UK Singles Chart number ones of the 1990s}}
Madonna has 13 number one hits in United Kingdom, a record for a female recording artist, spanning her number one for three decades: 1980s, 1990s and 2000s
In 1985, Madonna became the first female artist in UK chart history to hold the top-two positions of the chart simultaneously, with "[[Into the Groove]]" topping number one and "Holiday" the second place<ref name="mcaleer">{{harvnb|McAleer|2004|p=262}}</ref> By the end of 1985, Madonna achieved up another record with the song, becoming the first female artist to have eight UK top-ten singles in one calendar year.<ref>{{harvnb|Tobler|1991|p=198}}</ref> In 1987 when she published "La Isla Bonita", she became the female artist with the most number-one singles in the British chart history<ref>{{harvnb|Lazell|1989|p=311}}</ref>—a record that has since been maintained by Madonna to date<ref name="UKSInglesOne"/> Every single reached the UK Top 20 until 2008's "[[Miles Away (Madonna song)|Miles Away]]". Also, Madonna simultaneously topped the albums and singles charts 4 times in her career, which is unmatched by any other female artist. In 2014, [[Official Charts Company]] compiled her Top 40 biggest selling singles, with "[[Into the Groove]]" in the top with 870,000 copies.<ref name="Biggest40UK">{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/madonna-s-official-number-one-singles-sales-revealed-__3750/|title=Madonna's Official Number One Singles' Sales Revealed!|date=February 7, 2014|accessdate=April 2, 2015|publisher=Official Charts|author=Justin Myers}}</ref> Furthermore, Madonna had 71st Top 40 U.K. singles, the most for any female artist.<ref name="UKRecord"/> Her others milestones including, eleven Top 2 singles, sixty Top 10 and forty four Top 20 singles.

==== UK Albums Chart statistics ==== {{see also|List of artists by number of UK Albums Chart number ones|List of UK Albums Chart number ones of the 1990s|List of Platinum singles in the United Kingdom awarded since 2000|List of best-selling albums by year in the United Kingdom}}
She has 12 number-one albums with 9 studio albums —the most for any solo artist. Also, she has five number-two albums and twenty Top 5 albums, more than any other female artist. In 1986, ''True Blue'' opened at the top of the [[UK Albums Chart]] on July 12, 1986, making it the first album by American artist to debut at number one in British chart history.<ref name="ukalbum">{{cite web|url=http://www.theofficialcharts.com/archive-chart/_/3/1986-07-12/|title=UK Albums Chart – Week of July 12, 1986|date=July 12, 1986|accessdate=April 6, 2015|publisher=[[The Official Charts Company]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68ibwVIml?url=http://www.officialcharts.com/archive-chart/_/3/1986-07-12/|archivedate=June 26, 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Frith|Straw|Street|2001|p=16}}</ref> In 2012, with ''MDNA'' she became the first female in have an album in the number one during the 1980, 1990, 2000 and 2010.<ref name="MDNAfourdecades">{{cite web|title=Madonna y MDNA remueven los libros de récords musicales, ¡para siempre!|date=March 28, 2012|publisher=Impre.com}}</ref> Also, Madonna and [[Kylie Minogue]] are the only artists ever to have a number-one album and a number-one single in three different decades.
According to ''[[New Musical Express]]'' her albums ''The Immaculate Collection'' and ''Confessions on a Dance Floor'' are one of the 50 fastest selling albums ever in United Kingdom, selling 340,000 and 217,610 respectively. Making in the female artist with most entries.<ref name="fastalbum">{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/photos/50-fastest-selling-albums-ever/213617#/photo/1|title=50 fastest selling albums ever|accessdate=March 4, 2015|work=[[NME]]}}</ref> Both [[Michael Jackson]], Madonna had two of the [[List of best-selling albums of the 1980s in the United Kingdom|best selling albums of the decade 1980]] with ''True Blue'' (#9) and ''Like a Virgin'' (#17). Also during the 2000s, she figured [[List of best-selling albums of the 2000s (decade) in the United Kingdom|with two albums]] in the top 100 with ''Music'' and ''Confessions on a Dance Floor'' and she topped the [[List of UK Albums Chart Christmas number ones|UK chart Christmas]] with ''The Immaculate Collection'', making the first to the decade 1990s and occupied the record number one during nine weeks.

They said: You might not be able to run as fast as Michael Johnson, or sell as many records as Madonna.<ref name="GuinnessCulture">{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LqY3qCF-8pQC&q=%5BYou+might+not+be+able+to+run+as+fast+as+Michael+Johnson,+or+sell+as+many+records+as+Madonna,+but+everyone+can+set+a+record,+either+as+an+...+You+might+not+be+able+to+run+as+fast+as+Michael+Johnson,+or+sell+as+many+records+as+Madonna,+but+everyone+can+set+a+record,+either+as+an&dq=%5BYou+might+not+be+able+to+run+as+fast+as+Michael+Johnson,+or+sell+as+many+records+as+Madonna,+but+everyone+can+set+a+record,+either+as+an+...+You+might+not+be+able+to+run+as+fast+as+Michael+Johnson,+or+sell+as+many+records+as+Madonna,+but+everyone+can+set+a+record,+either+as+an&hl=es&sa=X&ei=WaspVdiNFpPHsQTpwYDIBA&ved=0CBsQ6AEwAA|title=Guinness World Records 2001|year=2001|author=Tim Footman|author-link=Tim Footman|accessdate=April 11, 2015}}</ref>
{|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- !scope="col" width=20%|Record title !scope="col" width=67%|Notes |- |The most ever paid for an item of clothing belonging to Madonna |£12,100 ($19,360), for a corset designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and sold at Christie's, London, UK, in May 1994, according to 1998 edition of ''The Guinness Book of Records''<ref>{{harvnb|McFarlan|1998|p=19|ref=https://books.google.com/books?id=rdU1xtIWJz0C&q=The+Guinness+Book+of+Records+Madonna&dq=The+Guinness+Book+of+Records+Madonna&hl=es&sa=X&ei=lyf7VKSqOMicNqvwgYgB&ved=0CFgQ6AEwBzgK}}</ref> |- |Most people dressed as Madonna at a single event/largest gathering of people dressed as Madonna |440 people who were dressed as Madonna on August 30, 2014 attended the annual Fool's Paradise Drag Party at the [[Fire Island Pines, New York]]<ref name="DressedasMadonna">{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonblade.com/2014/09/24/partygoers-dressed-madonna-set-record/|title=Partygoers dressed as Madonna set record|date=September 24, 2014|accessdate=March 9, 2015|work=[[Washington Blade]]}}</ref> |- |}

page.title: List of longest prison sentences served

revision.comment: /* Prisoners who served more than sixty years */
revision.text:
This is a list of '''longest prison sentences served''' by a single person, worldwide, without a period of freedom followed by a second conviction. These cases rarely coincide with the [[list of longest prison sentences|longest prison sentences]] given, because some countries have laws that don't allow sentences without [[parole]] or for convicts to remain in prison beyond a given number of years (regardless of their original conviction). {{legend2|#5CFF67|This color indicates cases where imprisonment is still ongoing|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} ==Prisoners who served more than sixty years== {| class="wikitable sortable" cellpadding="4px" |- ! style="width:76px;"| Name ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence start ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence end ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence duration ! style="width:100px;"| Country ! class="unsortable"| Description |- | Charles Fossard | 1903 | 1974 | 70 years, 303 days | {{Hs|AUS}} {{flagcountry|AUS}} | Homeless [[French Australian]] recluded in the [[J Ward|J Ward mental asylum]] in [[Ararat, Victoria]] after murdering an elderly man and stealing his boots. Died while still incarcerated at the age of 92.http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/9812376 |- | [[Paul Geidel|Paul Geidel Jr.]] | 1911 | 1980 | 68 years, 245 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest-serving [[incarceration in the United States|prison inmate in the United States]] whose sentence ended in release. Incarcerated from 1911, aged 17 and released 1980 at 86. He died in a nursing home in 1987, aged 93. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Francis Clifford Smith | 7 June 1950 | ongoing | {{ayd|1950|6|7}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Oldest prisoner in the United States. Sentenced to death for the murder of a nightwatchman during a robbery at a yacht club in July 1949, his sentence was commuted to life in prison in 1954, only two hours before his scheduled execution. |- | Johnson Van Dyke Grigsby | 1908 | 1974 | 66 years, 123 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Sentenced to life in prison for murder, he was denied parole 69 times before he was released at age 89. Returned to prison voluntarily, citing difficulty finding a job, but left again in 1976. Died in 1987, aged 101. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | John Phillips | 17 July 1952 | ongoing | {{ayd|1952|7|17}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[North Carolina]]. Convicted for the rape of a five-year-old girl.{{cite web|url=http://bailbondcity.com/north_carolina/ncdoc-inmate-PHILLIPS/0322466|title=PHILLIPS, JOHN PHILLIPS Inmate 0322466: North Carolina Prisons (DOC)|publisher=}} |- | [[William Heirens]] | 1946 | 2012 | 65 years, 181 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Known as the "Lipstick Killer". Reputed to be the longest surviving prisoner in [[Chicago]]. Died in prison. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Joseph Ligon | 1953 | ongoing | {{ayd|1953|12|18}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | The oldest juvenile lifer in the U.S., Ligon at age 15 was sentenced to life without parole for murder, a mandatory sentence at the time.{{Cite news|url=https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2017/05/17/nations-oldest-juvenile-lifer-refuses-parole-will-appeal-new-sentence/|title=Nation’s Oldest Juvenile Lifer Refuses Parole, Will Appeal New Sentence|date=2017-05-17|access-date=2018-10-08|language=en}} Ligon first rejected a resentencing and parole offer in 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/20161029_Juvenile_lifer__78__rejects_deal_for_parole___His_view_is__He_s_been_in_long_enough_.html|title=Juvenile lifer, 79, rejects deal for parole. 'His view is: He's been in long enough'|publisher=}} Ligon was again resentenced in 2017 and immediately eligible for parole but refused it, pending his appeal. Ligon contends that he should be resentenced to "time served" and released, so that can cut all ties to the justice system. |- | Clarence Marshall | 1950 | 2015 | 64 years, 70 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest-serving prisoner in [[Michigan]]. Sentenced to life in prison on one count of armed robbery and another of unarmed assault "with intent to rob and steal". Paroled. |- | [[Richard Honeck]] | 1899 | 1963 | 64 years, 44 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Aged 22, Honeck was sentenced to life in prison for the murder of a former school friend. He was paroled after 63 years and one month. He died in 1976, aged 97. |- | Howard Christensen | 1937 | 2001 | 64 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Sentenced to life without parole for the murder of a teacher in 1937, when he was 16, along with a 17-year-old accomplice who hanged himself in prison in 1943. His sentence was commuted to 200 years in the mid-1970s. Died in 2003, aged 82. |- | Charles Edret Ford | 1952 | 2016 | 64 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Prisoner incarcerated for the longest time who was found to be innocent on retrial, and the longest serving prisoner in [[Maryland]]. Ford, a black man, was convicted for murder by an all-white jury in 1952, when he was 20, and again for an assault in 1975 supposedly committed while he was on parole. The second victim identified a different man as her attacker but the judge argued that both men looked alike enough. Ford, at the time the only person present at his first conviction who was still alive, was granted retrials in 2015 for both charges because he had not been informed of his right to appeal the sentences. He was found innocent of both and released to a nursing home.{{cite web|url=http://www.thebaynet.com/articles/0316/manfreeatlastafter64yearsinprison.html|title=Man free at last after 64 years in prison|publisher=}} |- | Oliver Terpening | 1947 | 2010 | 63 years, 125 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Killed a school friend and three young girls and attempted to rape another girl because he wanted to know how it felt to kill somebody. He found the experience disappointing. Died in prison. |- | "Old" Bill Wallace | 1926 | 1989 | 63 years | {{Hs|AUS}} {{flagcountry|AUS}} | Imprisoned for shooting a man in an argument over a cigarette in a cafe of [[Melbourne]]. Died a month before his 108th birthday, still in prison, incarcerated in [[J Ward]]. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Walter H. Bourque Jr. | 1955 | ongoing | {{ayd|1955|12|11}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[New Hampshire]]. Serving a sentence of 99 years and six months for the axe murder of a four-year-old girl when he was 17. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Warren Nutter | 1956 | ongoing | {{ayd|1956|2|10}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Youngest man ever sentenced to death in [[Iowa]], when he was 18 years old, for the murder of a patrolman during a gas station robbery. Sentence commuted to life in prison in 1957.{{cite web|url=http://flashbak.com/death-row-stories-life-in-the-iowa-state-penitentiary-at-fort-madison-1956-47697/|title=Death Row Stories: Life In The Iowa State Penitentiary At Fort Madison (1956) -|publisher=}} |- | Hugh Alderman | 1917 | 1980 | 62 years, 192 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Florida]]. Escaped twice in 1919 and 1924. Moved to a mental hospital in 1927, where he died in 1980, aged 86. |- | [[Howard Unruh]] | 1949 | 2009 | 60 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | [[Mass murderer]] who killed 13 people and injured three in [[Camden, New Jersey]]. Recluded in a mental hospital without trial or conviction. |} ==Prisoners who served between fifty and sixty years== {| class="wikitable sortable" cellpadding="4px" |- ! style="width:76px;"| Name ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence start ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence end ! style="width:75px;"| Sentence duration ! style="width:100px;"| Country ! class="unsortable"| Description |- | Raymond L. Shuman | 13 June 1958 | 3 February 2018https://www.ktnv.com/news/inmate-who-has-been-behind-bars-for-60-years-dies-in-carson-city | 59 years, 7 months, 20 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Nevada]]. Jailed for the murder and robbery of two men while he and his partner (who was the one that pulled the trigger) were [[AWOL]] from the [[US Navy]]. Set another prisoner on fire in 1973 due to a dispute about leaving a window open. Died in 2018. |- | [[Jesse Pomeroy]] | December 1874 | September 29, 1932 | 57 years, nine months | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Teenage [[serial killer]] nicknamed "The Boy Fiend", who tortured nine younger children and killed two in [[Boston, Massachusetts]]. Sentenced to death when he was fifteen years old, this was changed to life in solitary confinement after two consecutive governors refused to sign his death warrant. The solitary confinement was lifted in 1917, and he died in 1932, still in prison. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Chester Weger | 4 April 1961 | ongoing | {{ayd|1961|4|4}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Convicted for the murder of three women in [[Starved Rock State Park]] in 1960. Last denied parole in November 2016.{{cite news |url=http://www.newstrib.com/free/weger-narrowly-denied-parole/article_b9dfcbc4-cb17-11e7-a3df-631e19a02e4a.html |title=Weger narrowly denied parole |first=Tom|last=Collins|publisher=La Salle (Illinois) News Tribune}} |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | Booker T. Hillery | 1962 | ongoing | {{ayd|1962|11|01}} | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[California]]. Originally sentenced to death but changed to life in prison in the 1970s. [[Vasquez v. Hillery|Appealed]], was retried and found guilty again in 1986. |- | [[Mehmet VI]] | 1861 | 1918 | 56 years | {{Hs|Ottoman Empire}} {{flagcountry|Ottoman Empire}} | Kept in the [[Seraglio]] and the [[Kafes]] from his birth to his accession to the throne, aged 56. He was both the last Ottoman prince to be ritually imprisoned by his family and the one who was imprisoned for the longest time. |- | Joe Carr | 1941 | 1997 | 56 years | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[Kansas]]. Convicted of murder for strangling a newborn and tossing his body in the [[Arkansas river]]. Carr refused to apply for parole until he was released, aged 79. |- | William Holly Griffith | 1915 | 1971 | 55 years, 359 days | {{Hs|USA}} {{flagcountry|USA}} | Longest serving prisoner in [[West Virginia]], known as "the bestial killer" and the "leading bad man" in the state. Sentenced to life for murdering the sheriff that was going to arrest him and a railway policeman during his escape to [[Ohio]], where he was arrested. Tried to flee prison several times, the last one when he was already suffering from [[cancer]]. Died in prison. |- |- style="background:#5CFF67;" | [[Hans-Georg Neumann]] | 1963 | ongoing | {{ayd|1963|5|30}} | {{Hs|GER}} {{flagcountry|GER}} | Abducted and shot a young couple at a lovers lane. Longest serving prisoner in Germany. |- | [[John Straffen]] | 1952 | 2007 | 55 years | {{Hs|UK}} {{flagcountry|UK}} | Multiple child killer. Sentenced to death for his third murder, which took place after he escaped from a mental hospital; the sentence was commuted to life in prison. {{Other uses}} [[Image:Midgard (Sö 56, Fyrby).jpg|350px|right|thumb|The runes ''a:miþkarþi'', [[Old Norse]] ''à Miðgarði'', meaning "in Midgard" – "in Middle Earth", on the [[Fyrby Runestone]] (Sö 56) in [[Södermanland]], [[Sweden]].]]
'''Midgard''' (an anglicised form of [[Old Norse language|Old Norse]] {{lang|non|Miðgarðr}}; [[Old English]] {{lang|ang|Middangeard}}, [[Swedish language|Swedish]] and [[Danish language|Danish]] ''Midgård'', [[Old Saxon]] {{lang|osx|Middilgard}}, [[Old High German]] {{lang|goh|Mittilagart}}, [[Gothic language|Gothic]] ''Midjun-gards''; "middle yard") is the name for [[Earth]] (equivalent in meaning to the Greek term {{lang |grc|[[Ecumene|οἰκουμένη]]}}, "inhabited") inhabited by and known to [[mannaz|humans]] in early Germanic cosmology, and specifically one of the [[Norse cosmology|Nine Worlds]] in [[Norse mythology]].
==Etymology== {{wiktionary|middangeard}} {{wiktionary|𐌼𐌹𐌳𐌾𐌿𐌽𐌲𐌰𐍂𐌳𐍃}} This name occurs in [[Old Norse language|Old Norse]] literature as {{lang|non|Miðgarðr}}. In [[Old Saxon]] ''[[Heliand]]'' it appears as {{lang|osx|Middilgard}} and in [[Old High German]] poem ''[[Muspilli]]'' it appears as {{lang |goh|Mittilagart}}. The [[Gothic language|Gothic]] form {{lang|got|Midjungards}} is attested in the [[Gospel of Luke]] as a translation of the Greek word {{lang |grc|[[Ecumene|οἰκουμένη]]}}. The word is present in [[Old English]] epic and poetry as {{lang |ang|Middangeard}}; later transformed to {{lang |enm|Middellærd}} or {{lang |enm|Mittelerde}} ("[[Middle-earth (disambiguation)|Middle-earth]]") in [[Middle English]] literature.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=Midgard | title = Online Etymology Dictionary | contribution = Midgard}}.</ref>
All these forms are from a [[Common Germanic]] ''*midja-gardaz'' (''*meddila-'', ''*medjan-''), a compound of ''[[:wikt:Appendix:Proto-Germanic/midjaz|*midja-]]'' "middle" and ''[[:wikt:Appendix:Proto-Germanic/gardaz|*gardaz]]'' "yard, enclosure". In early Germanic cosmology, the term stands alongside ''[[:wikt:world|world]]'' ([[Old English]] ''weorold'', [[Old Saxon]] ''werold'', [[Old High German]] ''weralt'', [[Old Frisian]] ''warld'' and [[Old Norse]] ''verǫld''), from a [[Common Germanic]] compound ''*wira-alđiz'', the "age of men".<ref>Orel, Vladimir E. (2003). ''A Handbook of Germanic Etymology''. Leiden: Brill. p. 462. {{ISBN|90-04-12875-1}}</ref>
==Old Norse== Midgard is a realm in [[Norse mythology]]. It is one of the Nine Worlds—the only one that is completely visible to mankind (the others may intersect with this visible realm but are mostly invisible). Pictured as placed somewhere in the middle of [[Yggdrasil]], Midgard is between the land of [[Niflheim]]—the land of ice—to the north and [[Muspelheim]]—the land of fire—to the south.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Midgard|title=Midgard {{!}} Norse mythology|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2017-08-29|language=en}}</ref> Midgard is surrounded by a world of water, or ocean, that is impassable. The ocean is inhabited by the great sea serpent [[Jörmungandr]] (Miðgarðsormr), who is so huge that he encircles the world entirely, grasping his own tail. The concept is similar to that of the [[Ouroboros]]. Midgard was also connected to Asgard, the home of the gods, by the [[Bifröst]], the rainbow bridge, guarded by [[Heimdallr]].
In Norse mythology, ''Miðgarðr'' became applied to the wall around the world that the gods constructed from the eyebrows of the giant [[Ymir]] as a defense against the [[Jötunn|Jotuns]] who lived in [[Jotunheim]], east of ''Manheimr'', the "home of men", a word used to refer to the entire world. The gods slew the giant [[Ymir]], the first created being, and put his body into the central void of the universe, creating the world out of his body: his flesh constituting the land, his [[Ymir's blood|blood]] the oceans, his bones the mountains, his teeth the cliffs, his hairs the trees, and his brains the clouds. Aurgelmir's skull was held by four dwarfs, Nordri, Sudri, Austri, and Vestri, who represent the four points on the compass and became the dome of heaven. The sun, moon, and stars were said to be scattered sparks in the skull.
[[Image:Sö 56, Fyrby.jpg|200px|right|thumb|The Fyrby Runestone.]] According to the [[Eddas]], Midgard will be destroyed at [[Ragnarök]], the battle at the end of the world. Jörmungandr will arise from the ocean, poisoning the land and sea with his venom and causing the sea to rear up and lash against the land. The final battle will take place on the plane of [[Vígríðr]], following which Midgard and almost all life on it will be destroyed, with the earth sinking into the sea, only to rise again, fertile and green when the cycle repeats and the creation begins again.
Although most surviving instances of the word Midgard refer to spiritual matters, it was also used in more mundane situations, as in the [[Viking Age]] [[runestone]] poem from the inscription [[Fyrby Runestone|Sö 56]] from Fyrby:
{| | :Iak væit Hastæin :þa Holmstæin brøðr, :mænnr rynasta :a Miðgarði, :sattu stæin :ok stafa marga :æfti<small>R</small> Frøystæin, :faður sinn.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://skaldic.arts.usyd.edu.au/db.php?table=verses&id=10055 | title = Skaldic Poetry of the Scandinavian Middle Ages | publisher = USYD | place = [[Australia|AU]]}} for a version in normalized [[Old Norse orthography]].</ref> | :I know Hásteinn :Holmsteinns brother, :the most rune-skilled :men in Middle Earth, :placed a stone :and many letters :in memory of Freysteinn, :their father. | |}
The [[Danish language|Danish]] and [[Swedish language|Swedish]] form {{lang|sv|Midgård}} or {{lang|da|Midgaard}}, the [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] {{lang|no|Midgard}} or {{lang|no|Midgård}}, as well as the [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]] and [[Faroese language|Faroese]] form {{lang|is|Miðgarður}}, all derive from the Old Norse term.
==Old and Middle English== The name ''middangeard'' occurs six times in the [[Old English language|Old English]] epic poem ''[[Beowulf]]'', and is the same word as Midgard in [[Old Norse]]. The term is equivalent in meaning to the Greek term [[Oikoumene]], as referring to the known and inhabited world.
The concept of Midgard occurs many times in [[Middle English]]. The association with ''earth'' (OE ''eorðe'') in Middle English ''middellærd'', ''middelerde'' is by [[popular etymology]]; the continuation of ''geard'' "enclosure" is ''[[yard (land)|yard]]''. An early example of this transformation is from the [[Ormulum]]:
::''þatt ure Drihhtin wollde / ben borenn i þiss middellærd''
::that our Lord wanted / be born in this middle-earth.
The usage of "[[Middle-earth]]" as a name for a setting was popularized by Old English scholar [[J. R. R. Tolkien]] in his ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' and other fantasy works; he was originally inspired by the references to ''middangeard'' and ''[[Éarendel]]'' in the Old English poem ''[[Crist]]''.
==Old High German== ''Mittilagart'' is mentioned in the 9th-century [[Old High German]] ''[[Muspilli]]'' (v. 54) meaning "the world" as opposed to the sea and the heavens: ::''muor varsuuilhit sih, suilizot lougiu der himil,'' ::''mano uallit, prinnit mittilagart''
::Sea is swallowed, flaming burn the heavens, ::Moon falls, Midgard burns

'''Molecular epidemiology''' is a branch of [[epidemiology]] and [[medical science]] that focuses on the contribution of potential genetic and environmental risk factors, identified at the molecular level, to the [[etiology]], distribution and prevention of disease within families and across populations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pitt.edu/~kkr/molepi.html |title=What is Molecular Epidemiology? |date=28 July 1998|work=Molecular Epidemiology Homepage|publisher=University of Pittsburgh|accessdate=15 January 2010}}</ref> This field has emerged from the integration of [[molecular biology]] into traditional epidemiological research. [[Molecular]] [[epidemiology]] improves our understanding of the [[pathogenesis]] of disease by identifying specific pathways, [[molecules]] and [[gene]]s that influence the risk of developing disease.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aacr.org/home/scientists/working-groups--task-forces/molecular-epidemiology-working-group/what-is-molecular-epidemiology.aspx |title=What is Molecular Epidemiology? |publisher=aacr.org |accessdate=2008-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080303221258/http://www.aacr.org/home/scientists/working-groups--task-forces/molecular-epidemiology-working-group/what-is-molecular-epidemiology.aspx |archivedate=2008-03-03 |df= }}</ref><ref>[[Miquel Porta]], editor. Greenland S, Hernán M, dos Santos Silva I, Last JM, associate editors (2014). ''[http://global.oup.com/academic/product/a-dictionary-of-epidemiology-9780199976737?cc=us&lang=en A dictionary of epidemiology]'', 6th. edition. New York: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|9780199976737}}</ref> More broadly, it seeks to establish understanding of how the interactions between genetic traits and environmental exposures result in disease.<ref>{{cite journal |author= Porta, M.|title= Incomplete overlapping of biological, clinical, and environmental information in molecular epidemiological studies: a variety of causes and a cascade of consequences |journal= J Epidemiol Community Health |date= 2002 |volume= 56 |issue= 10 |pages= 734–738|pmid= 1732039 |doi= 10.1136/jech.56.10.734 |pmc= 1732039 }}</ref>
== History == The term "molecular epidemiology" was first coined by Kilbourne in a 1973 article entitled "The molecular epidemiology of influenza".<ref>{{cite journal |author=Kilbourne ED |title=The molecular epidemiology of influenza |journal=J Infect Dis |date=Apr 1973 |volume=127 |issue=4 |pages=478–87 |pmid=4121053 |doi=10.1093/infdis/127.4.478}}</ref> The term became more formalized with the formulation of the first book on ''Molecular Epidemiology: Principles and Practice'' by Schulte and Perera.<ref>{{cite book |title= Molecular Epidemiology: Principles and Practice |last1=Schulte |first1= Paul A. |last2=Perera |first2=Frederica P. |year=1993 |publisher=[[Academic Press]] |isbn=0-12-632346-1 |pages=588}}</ref> At the heart of this book is the impact of advances in molecular research that have given rise to and enable the measurement and exploitation of the [[biomarker]] as a vital tool to link traditional molecular and epidemiological research strategies to understand the underlying mechanisms of disease in populations.
== Modern use == While most molecular epidemiology studies are using conventional disease designation system for an outcome (with the use of exposures at the molecular level), compelling evidence indicates that disease evolution represents inherently heterogeneous process differing from person to person. Conceptually, each individual has a unique disease process different from any other individual ("the unique disease principle"),<ref>Ogino S, Lochhead P, Chan AT, Nishihara R, Cho E, Wolpin BM, Meyerhardt AJ, Meissner A, Schernhammer ES, Fuchs CS, Giovannucci E. Molecular pathological epidemiology of epigenetics: emerging integrative science to analyze environment, host, and disease. Mod Pathol 2013;26:465-484.</ref> considering uniqueness of the [[exposome]] and its unique influence on [[Molecular pathology|molecular pathologic]] process in each individual. Studies to examine the relationship between an exposure and molecular pathologic signature of disease (particularly, cancer) became increasingly common throughout the 2000s. However, the use of molecular pathology in epidemiology posed unique challenges including lack of standardized methodologies and guidelines as well as paucity of interdisciplinary experts and training programs.<ref>Sherman ME, Howatt W, Blows FM, Pharoah P, Hewitt SM, Garcia-Closas M. Molecular pathology in epidemiologic studies: a primer on key considerations. Cancer Epidemiol Biomarkers Prev 2010;19(4):966-972.</ref><ref>Ogino S, King EE, Beck AH, Sherman ME, Milner DA, Giovannucci E. Interdisciplinary education to integrate pathology and epidemiology: Towards molecular and population-level health science. Am J Epidemiol 2012;176:659-667.</ref> The use of "molecular epidemiology" for this type of research masked the presence of these challenges, and hindered the development of methods and guidelines.<ref>Kuller LH. Invited commentary: the 21st century epidemiologist--a need for different training? Am J Epidemiol 2012;176(8):668-671.</ref><ref>Ogino S, Beck AH, King EE, Sherman ME, Milner DA, Giovannucci E. Ogino et al. respond to "The 21st century epidemiologist". Am J Epidemiol 2012;176:672-674.</ref> Furthermore, the concept of disease heterogeneity appears to conflict with the premise that individuals with the same disease name have similar etiologies and disease processes.
== Analytical methods == The genome of a bacterial species fundamentally determines its identity. Thus, [[gel electrophoresis]] techniques like [[pulsed-field gel electrophoresis]] can be used in molecular epidemiology to comparatively analyze patterns of bacterial chromosomal fragments and to elucidate the genomic content of bacterial cells. Due to its widespread use and ability to analyse epidemiological information about most bacterial pathogens based on their molecular markers, pulsed-field gel electrophoresis is relied upon heavily in molecular epidemiological studies.<ref>{{cite journal |author= Goering, R.|title= Pulsed field gel electrophoresis: A review of application and interpretation in the molecular epidemiology of infectious disease |journal= Infection, Genetics and Evolution |date= 6 August 2010 |volume= 10|issue= 7 |pages= 866–875|pmid= 20692376|doi=10.1016/j.meegid.2010.07.023}}</ref>
== Applications == Molecular epidemiology allows for an understanding of the molecular outcomes and implications of diet, lifestyle, and environmental exposure, particularly how these choices and exposures result in acquired genetic mutations and how these mutations are distributed throughout selected populations through the use of biomarkers and genetic information. Molecular epidemiological studies are able to provide additional understanding of previously-identified [[risk factor]]s and disease mechanisms.<ref>{{cite journal|date=2002|title=The science and art of molecular epidemiology|journal=J Epidemiol Community Health|volume=56|issue=10|pages=728–729|doi=10.1136/jech.56.10.728|pmid=1732025|author=Slattery, M.|pmc=1732025}}</ref> Specific applications include: * Molecular surveillance of disease risk factors * Measuring the geographical and temporal distribution of disease risk factors * Characterizing the evolution of pathogens and classifying new pathogen species<ref>{{cite journal|date=2014|title=Strengthening the Reporting of Molecular Epidemiology for Infectious Diseases (STROME-ID): an extension of the STROBE statement|journal=Lancet Infect Dis|volume=14|issue=4|pages=341–352|doi=10.1016/S1473-3099(13)70324-4|pmid=24631223|author=Field, N.}}</ref>
== Criticism == While the use of advanced molecular analysis techniques within the field of molecular epidemiology is providing the larger field of epidemiology with greater means of analysis, [[Miquel Porta]] identified several challenges that the field of molecular epidemiology faces, particularly selecting and incorporating requisite applicable data in an unbiased manner.<ref>{{cite journal|date=2002|title=Incomplete overlapping of biological, clinical, and environmental information in molecular epidemiological studies: a variety of causes and a cascade of consequences|journal=J Epidemiol Community Health|volume=56|issue=10|pages=734–738|doi=10.1136/jech.56.10.734|pmid=1732039|author=Porta, M.|pmc=1732039}}</ref> Limitations of molecular epidemiological studies are similar in nature to those of generic epidemiological studies, that is, samples of convenience - both of the target population and genetic information, small sample sizes, inappropriate statistical methods, poor quality control, and poor definition of target populations.<ref>{{cite journal|date=2002|title=The science and art of molecular epidemiology|journal=J Epidemiol Community Health|volume=56|issue=10|pages=728–729|doi=10.1136/jech.56.10.728|pmid=1732025|author=Slattery, M.|pmc=1732025}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Genetic epidemiology]] * [[Genome-wide association study]] * [[Genomics]] * [[Molecular medicine]] * [[Personalized medicine]] * [[Precision medicine]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=August 2017}} {{POV|date=June 2017}} }}
'''New constitutionalism''' is derived from the classical [[Neoliberalism|neo-liberalism]] framework and represents a set of political policies that promote a new global order.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Dierckx|first=Sacha|date=2013-12-01|title=After the Crisis and Beyond the New Constitutionalism? The Case of the Free Movement of Capital|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/14747731.2013.814450|journal=Globalizations|volume=10|issue=6|pages=803–818|doi=10.1080/14747731.2013.814450|issn=1474-7731}}</ref> The goal of new constitutionalism is to separate the democratic and economic practices by shifting economic aims from the regional and national level to the global level through constitutional framework.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Gill|first=Stephen|date=1998-02-01|title=New constitutionalism, democratisation and global political economy|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/14781159808412845|journal=Pacifica Review: Peace, Security & Global Change|volume=10|issue=1|pages=23–38|doi=10.1080/14781159808412845|issn=1323-9104}}</ref> The purpose of this shift is to create global supremacy and promote a free [[Capitalism|capitalist]] system.<ref name=":0" />
Central ideas of neoliberalism have been advanced to create policies and practices to achieve [[global governance]].<ref name=":1" /> New constitutionalism provides power to the private realm and limits power of state governance and public corporations.<ref name=":0" /> The transferring of power creates an informal self-regulatory setting allowing for the dismissal of public scrutiny and transparency.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=New Constitutionalism and World Order|last=Gill|first=Stephen|last2=Cutler|first2=Claire|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2014|isbn=978-1-107-05369-4|location=Cambridge, United Kingdom; New York, NY|pages=7}}</ref> New constitutionalism has reshaped the structure of control to allow “locking in” mechanisms to occur to prevent intervention from the democratic realm and to enhance economic objectives.<ref name=":2" /> This protects markets from regional interference and allows global influence in order to promote [[imperialism]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=The New Constitutionalism: International and Private Rule in The New Global Order|last=McBride|first=Stephen|publisher=University of Toronto Press|year=2011|isbn=978-1-4426-0365-3|editor-last=McBride|editor-first=Stephen|location=Toronto|pages=21|editor-last2=Teeple|editor-first2=Gary}}</ref>
The development of new constitutionalism is the result of [[globalization]] and the growing need for [[global hegemony]].<ref name=":2" /> Institutions have gained power in regards to trade, mobility, and flexibility through the framework of new constitutionalism.<ref name=":3" /> The [[World Trade Organization]], [[International Monetary Fund]], the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]], and the [[European Union]] are all actors contributing to the power of global supremacy.<ref name=":3" />
New constitutionalism as a political order emerged in the latter half of the 20th century and the term was coined by academic[[Stephen Gill (political scientist)|Stephen Gill]].<ref name=":1"/> The need for economic constitutional change was the result of crisis in political order correspondingly to the [[Russian Revolution]] and the [[Cold War]] as well as the progress of [[globalization]] through technological means.<ref name=":1" /> Since then the disciplinary has grown in acceptance due to the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|global financial crisis]] of 2007 and the need for largescale stabilization in its aftermath.<ref name=":0" /> Theorists have subsequently developed the social and economic practices both in support and disagreement of the framework to provide a comparative outlook.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hilbink|first=Lisa|year=2008|title=Assessing the New Constitutionalism|url=https://www.jstor.org.subzero.lib.uoguelph.ca/stable/20434076?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents|journal=Comparative Politics|volume=40 [2]|pages=227–245|issn=0010-4159}}</ref>
== Origins == New constitutionalism formed in the 1980s as the result of a growing world order and the “worldwide market revolution.”<ref name=":2" /> The end of the [[Cold War]] represented an ideological shift and the need for transformation.<ref name=":2" /> This shift was reiterated by [[Margaret Thatcher|Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher]] declaring the depletion of [[socialism]] and the rise of [[conservatism]] and [[liberalism]].<ref name=":2" /> As society progressed it allowed for the evolution of capital mobility, [[Multinational corporation|transnational corporation]] and the expansion of the world market.<ref name=":2" /> The [[Great Depression]] and the aftermath of [[World War II]] reflected the need for reform.<ref name=":1" /> Reform would redirect economic and political practices, ensuring benefits for all through the creation of global institutions.<ref name=":5">Falk, R. (2014). New Constitutionalism and geopolitics: notes on legality and legitimacy and prospects for a just new constitutionalism. Edited by ''Cutler, A., & Gill, S.'' ''In New constitutionalism and world order.'' Cambridge, United Kingdom; New York, NY: Cambridge University Press, 295-312. {{ISBN|978-1-107-05369-4}}.</ref>
Neo-liberal supremacy through the dominance of the [[United States]] and the [[Soviet Union]] allowed for geopolitical reconfiguration increasing the need for new political order.<ref name=":2" /> Additionally the lack of consistency among nation-state principles and the constant interruption from democratic power influenced the need to provide sustainable long term economic goals by limiting [[Executive (government)|executive]] and [[Legislature|legislative]] branches of government using [[Constitution|constitutional framework]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4">Cutler, A. Claire. (2016) "Transformations in Statehood, the Investor-State Regime, and the New Constitutionalism." ''Indiana Journal of Global Legal Studies'' 23, no. 1: 95-125.</ref> New constitutionalism has become prominent in the aftermath of the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|2007 global financial crisis]] as a result of the need to bypass formal trade rules and democratic controls.<ref name=":0" /><ref>Schneiderman, D. (2014). How to govern differently: neo-liberal, new constitutionalism and international investment law. Edited by ''Cutler, A., & Gill, S.'' ''In New constitutionalism and world order.'' Cambridge, United Kingdom; New York, NY: Cambridge University Press, 159-175. {{ISBN|978-1-107-05369-4}}. </ref>
== Framework == There are four main [[Policy|policies]] to define new constitutionalism.<ref name=":2" /> The first represents the development of a constitutional structure for the global market that dictates the public, private and international powers.<ref name=":2" /> These international economic agreements or “[[constitution]]s” resemble political constitutions and thus ensure [[sovereignty]].<ref name=":3" /> The economic power is being shifted from the national to the international as well as from the public to the private to provide growth and sustainability.<ref name=":3" />
Second is the separation of economic policies from domestic influence.<ref name=":2" /> This allows for capitalist markets to grow as well as extending the commodity form and the market forces.<ref name=":2" />''' ''' This separation insulates economic policies from governing regulatory powers as well as the public demand for transparency.<ref name=":3" /> [[Economic Liberation Movement|Economic liberation]] is usually accompanied by political backlash, by disconnecting these two dynamisms suppresses democratic involvement.<ref name=":1" /> [[World Bank Group|The World Bank]] advocates for the restriction of democratic participation and limitations imposed in the economic realm by creating a hierarchical system of representation.<ref name=":1" />
Thirdly is creating “locking in” mechanisms which incorporate; laws, rules, regulations, procedures and institutions.<ref name=":2" /> This mechanism puts limitations on legislative and policy autonomy.<ref name=":1" /> Agreements are formulated to “lock in” [[Neoliberalism|neoliberal]] content through legal guarantees and sanctions.<ref name=":1" /> These agreements are difficult, even impossible to change which makes economic policies autonomous.<ref name=":3" />
Lastly this process diminished the need for formal accountability.<ref name=":2" /> New constitutionalism has created a flexible system giving privileges to [[Multinational corporation|international corporations]] and private entities creating a “double” legal standard.<ref name=":2" /> This concept diminished the “watchdog” and gives the flexibility for self-regulation.<ref name=":2" /> This instrument is based on the international gold standard of the [[19th century|nineteenth century]] which gave rights to investor to avoid certain jurisdictions.<ref name=":1" /> Permitting deregulation of financial services and trade investment avoids popular pressures and limits the need for transparency.<ref name=":4" /> Minimizing liability and ensuring private authority the economic sector becomes more efficient, functional and practical.<ref name=":6">Cutler, C. (2011). The Privatization of Authority in the Global Political Economy''.'' Edited by McBride, S., & Teeple, G. ''In'' ''Relations of global power: Neoliberal order and disorder''. (p.41-59). Toronto: University of Toronto Press. {{ISBN|978-1-4426-0365-3}}</ref>
== Institutions == At the global and regional level institutions are implementing the new constitutionalism framework to advance [[global governance]] by upholding the rights of private corporations and promoting a free [[Capitalism|capitalist]] society.<ref name=":3" /> These institutions policies will ensure [[economic growth]] at the global level.<ref name=":7">Sinclair, S. (2014). Trade agreements, the new constitutionalism and public services. Edited by ''Cutler, A., & Gill, S.'' ''In New constitutionalism and world order.'' Cambridge, United Kingdom; New York, NY: Cambridge University Press, 179-195. {{ISBN|978-1-107-05369-4}}</ref>
=== Global === The [[World Trade Organization]] [[World Trade Organization|(WTO)]] is a prominent figure in governing the [[World economy|global economy]].<ref name=":3" /> Formally it was the responsibility of [[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade|General Agreement of Tariffs and Trade]] built on [[Neoliberalism|neoliberal]] principles but lacked the greater power adapted through new constitutionalism.<ref name=":3" /> The [[World Trade Organization]] represents a governing global entity which has adapted to the principles of new constitutionalism.<ref name=":3" /> The [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] main purpose is to limit national interference in the global market and challenge any nation-state regulations that could be detrimental to the economy.<ref name=":3" /> Any economic alternatives that are proposed by nations can be discredited by the [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] as well as restricting governments ability to implement policy in international jurisdiction.<ref name=":3" /> The [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] represents the freedom of markets and allowing investors to capitalize in a [[world economy]], by doing so provides protection to the private sector.<ref name=":3" /> Stephen McBride describes the [[World Trade Organization]] as having “quasi-judicial and quasi-constitutional aura.”<ref name=":3" /> The judicial and constitutional supremacy highlights the difficulty in challenging the organizations because of lock in mechanisms.<ref name=":3" />
=== Regional === The [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] ([[North American Free Trade Agreement|NAFTA]]) is a considered a regional governing entity that encompasses the principles of new constitutionalism.<ref name=":3" /> [[Ronald Reagan|President Ronald Regan]] referred to the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] as a “new economic constitution.”<ref name=":3" /> Constitution because the agreement provided restrictions on government intrusion, rights to certain actors and enforcement mechanisms.<ref name=":3" /> The binding agreement afforded rights to both foreign and domestic investor to protect the interests of private capital and corporations.<ref name=":7" /> By limiting government powers the agreement locked in private interests and reduced governments ability to expand or restore [[public service]]s in [[free trade]].<ref name=":7" />
== Criticisms == Focus at the global level has resulted in hostility between the public and private realms within [[nation state]]s.<ref name=":6" /> This hostility creates a political struggle between the private sector who safeguard the rights of capital and the public who want to control [[capitalism]] politically, democracy and socially.<ref name=":0" /> The control is being denationalized and delocalized causing negative repercussions at state level.<ref name=":4" /> New constitutionalism lacks political will and can have detrimental effects to global dignity and future generations.<ref name=":5" /> Dividing economic policies from domestic creates disturbances within the civil society.<ref name=":4" /> [[Human rights]], [[Environmental issue|environmental concerns]] and [[public service]]s are being devalued because of the lack of economic concern.<ref name=":4" />
New constitutionalism favours the [[Elitism|elitists]] providing preferential treatment and widening the [[Economic inequality|social gap]].<ref name=":4" /> [[International financial institutions]], [[investor]]s and bond-raters are holding higher positions of authority than governments or nation-states furthering global supremacy.<ref name=":1" /> There is an urgent need for surveillance, policy making power, regulations and transparency economic outcomes are not solely focused on monetary gain but [[Humanitarianism|humanitarian]] concerns as well.<ref name=":5" /> The absence of accountability and democratic authority has led many countries to depart from the constitutional framework and reclaim their [[sovereignty]] as independent nations.<ref name=":4" /> [[Australia]] has begun to constrain the advancements of new constitutionalism while many [[South America]] states have begun to exit the global regime completely.<ref name=":4" /> [[Canada]] and the [[United States]] have begun to form provisions to improve the democratic power within the global order and no longer allow for their governments to be immobilized.<ref name=":4" />
