{{pressrelease|date=March 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox holiday | holiday_name = Environment day | type = International | image = Ecologia.jpg | official_name = UN World Environment Day | nickname = Eco Day,Environment Day, WED(world environment day) | significance = Environmental issues awareness | duration = 1 day | date = 5 June | firsttime = {{start date and age|df=yes|5 June 1974}} | observances = Environment Protection }} [[File:Indian Navy - World Environment Day - 2016 (1).jpg|thumb|World Environment Day in India]] '''World Environment Day''' ('''WED''') is celebrated on the 5th of June every year, and is the [[United Nations|United Nation's]] principal vehicle for encouraging awareness and action for the [[environmental protection|protection of our environment]]. First held in 1974, it has been a flagship campaign for raising awareness on emerging [[environmental issue]]s from [[marine pollution]], human [[overpopulation]], and [[global warming]], to [[sustainable consumption]] and wildlife crime. WED has grown to become a global platform for public outreach, with participation from over 143 countries annually. Each year, WED has a new theme that major corporations, NGOs, communities, governments and celebrities worldwide adopt to advocate environmental causes. ==History== World Environment Day [WED] was established by the [[United Nations General Assembly|UN General Assembly]] in 1972{{Cite web|url=http://www.un.org/en/events/environmentday/background.shtml|title=World Environment Day - 5 June|website=www.un.org|language=EN|access-date=2017-12-19}} on the first day of the [[United Nations Conference on the Human Environment|Stockholm Conference on the Human Environment]], resulting from discussions on the integration of human interactions and the environment. Two years later, in 1974 the first WED was held with the theme "Only One Earth". Even though WED celebration have been held annually since 1974, in 1987 the idea for rotating the center of these activities through selecting different host countries began. == Annual themes and major initiatives and accomplishments == {{expand section|date=January 2016}} For almost five decades, World Environment Day has been raising awareness, supporting action, and driving change. Here is a timeline of key accomplishments in WEDs’ history: ===2018=== The theme for 2018 is "Beat Plastic Pollution". The host nation is India.{{Cite web|url=http://worldenvironmentday.global/|title=World Environment Day|website=worldenvironmentday.global|language=en|access-date=2018-06-05}} By choosing this Theme, it is aimed that people may strive to change their everyday lives to reduce the heavy burden of [[plastic pollution]]. People should be free from the over-reliance on single-use or disposables, as they have severe environmental consequences. We should liberate our natural places, our wildlife - and our own health from plastics.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/world-environment-day-2018-live-updates-host-nation-india-focuses-on-beat-plastic-pollution-theme-1862462|title=World Environment Day 2018 LIVE: Host Nation India Focuses On 'Beat Plastic Pollution' Theme|work=NDTV.com|access-date=2018-06-05}} Indian government pledged to eliminate all single use of plastic in India by 2022.{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/india-aims-to-partner-with-un-to-promote-use-of-solar-energy/articleshow/64476669.cms|title=India aims to partner with UN to promote use of solar energy|date=2018-06-06|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-06-06}} ===2017=== The theme for 2017 was 'Connecting People to Nature – in the city and on the land, from the poles to the equator'. The host nation was Canada.[http://worldenvironmentday.global/host-country/canada-natural-heritage-heart-national-identit 2017 Host country named as Canada, UNEP, 31 Jan 2017] === 2016 === The 2016 WED was organized under the theme "Go wild for life". This edition of the WED aims to reduce and prevent the illegal trade in wildlife.{{Cite news|url=http://sdg.iisd.org/events/world-environment-day-2016/|title=Event: World Environment Day 2016 {{!}} SDG Knowledge Hub {{!}} IISD|last=Hub|first=IISD's SDG Knowledge|access-date=2017-12-19|language=en-US}} [[Angola]] was chosen as the host country of the 2016 WED during the [[2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP21]] in Paris.{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201512141926.html|title=Angola to Host World Environment Day in 2016|date=2015-12-14|work=Angola Press Agency (Luanda)|access-date=2017-12-19}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.climateactionprogramme.org/news/angola_to_host_world_environment_day_2016|title=Angola to host World Environment Day 2016|last=Programme|first=Climate Action|website=www.climateactionprogramme.org|language=en|access-date=2017-12-19}}[[File:Activities for world environment day in Bhopal (8).jpg|thumb|Activities for world environment day in [[Bhopal]]]] === 2015 === The Slogan of the 2015 edition of the World Environment Day is "Seven Billion Dreams. One Planet. Consume with Care". The slogan was picked through a voting process on social media.{{Cite news|url=http://sdg.iisd.org/events/world-environment-day-2015/|title=Event: World Environment Day 2015 {{!}} SDG Knowledge Hub {{!}} IISD|last=Hub|first=IISD's SDG Knowledge|access-date=2017-12-19|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://europa.eu/capacity4dev/unep/blog/vote-your-world-environment-day-2015-slogan|title=Vote for your World Environment Day 2015 slogan {{!}} capacity4dev.eu|website=europa.eu|language=en|access-date=2017-12-19}} In Saudi Arabia, 15 women recycled 2000 plastic bags to crochet a mural in support of the WED 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://web.unep.org/ourplanet/september-2015/unep-work/world-environment-day-2015|title=World Environment Day 2015 :: Our Planet|website=web.unep.org|access-date=2017-12-19}} In India, [[Narendra Modi]] planted a Kadamb sapling to celebrate the World Environment Day and raise awareness for Environment.{{Cite news|url=https://www.narendramodi.in/pm-plants-kadamb-sapling-on-world-environment-day-136145|title=PM plants "Kadamb" sapling on World Environment Day|work=www.narendramodi.in|access-date=2017-12-19}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.microfinancemonitor.com/why-pm-modi-planted-kadamb-sapling-world-environment-day/33305|title=Why PM Modi planted ‘Kadamb’ sapling on World Environment Day?|date=2015-06-05|work=Microfinance Monitor|access-date=2017-12-19|language=en-US}} Italy is the host country of the 43rd edition of the WED. The celebrations took place as part of [[Expo 2015|Milan Expo]] around the theme: Feeding the Planet - Energy for Life.{{Cite news|url=https://www.treehugger.com/culture/italy-hosts-official-world-environment-day-celebrations-expo-milano.html|title=Italy hosts the official World Environment Day celebrations at Expo Milano|work=TreeHugger|access-date=2017-12-19}} === 2014 === The Theme of the 2014 WED is : International Year of Small Islands Developing States (SIDS). By choosing this Theme the UN General Assembly aimed to highlight the development Challenges and successes of the SIDS. In 2014, the World Environment Day focused on global warming and its impact on ocean levels.{{Cite web|url=https://www.environment.gov.za/event/international/2014world_environmentday|title=World {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} [[File:World Heritage Logo global.svg|thumb|[[Logo]] of the [[UNESCO|United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] (UNESCO) [[World Heritage Committee]]]] A '''World Heritage site''' is a landmark or area which is selected by the [[United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] ([[UNESCO]]) as having cultural,Ann Marie Sullivan, Cultural Heritage & New Media: A Future for the Past, 15 J. Marshall Rev. Intell. Prop. L. 604 (2016) https://repository.jmls.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1392&context=ripl historical, scientific or other form of significance, and is legally protected by international treaties. The sites are judged important to the collective interests of humanity. To be selected, a World Heritage site must be an already classified landmark, unique in some respect as a geographically and historically identifiable place having special cultural or physical significance (such as an ancient ruin or historical structure, building, city, complex, desert, forest, island, lake, monument, mountain, or [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/cobi.12976/full wilderness area]). It may signify a remarkable accomplishment of humanity, and serve as evidence of our intellectual history on the planet.{{cite web|last1=Centre|first1=UNESCO World Heritage|title=The Criteria for Selection|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|website=whc.unesco.org|accessdate=1 February 2018|language=en}} The sites are intended for practical conservation for posterity, which otherwise would be subject to risk from human or animal trespassing, unmonitored/uncontrolled/unrestricted access, or threat from local administrative negligence. Sites are demarcated by UNESCO as protected zones.{{cite web|title=World Heritage|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/about/|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090630023048/http://whc.unesco.org/en/about/|archivedate=30 June 2009|df=dmy-all}} [[Lists of World Heritage Sites|The list]] is maintained by the international World Heritage Program administered by the UNESCO [[World Heritage Committee]], composed of 21 states parties which are elected by their General Assembly.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/comittee/|title=The World Heritage Committee|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Site|accessdate=14 October 2006|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061109181158/http://whc.unesco.org/en/comittee/|archivedate=9 November 2006|df=dmy-all}} The programme catalogues, names, and conserves sites of outstanding [[cultural heritage|cultural]] or [[natural heritage|natural]] importance to the common culture and heritage of [[World population|humanity]]. Under certain conditions, listed sites can obtain funds from the World Heritage Fund. The program began with the ''Convention Concerning the Protection of the World's Cultural and Natural Heritage'',[http://whc.unesco.org/archive/convention-en.pdf Convention Concerning the Protection of World's Cultural and Natural Heritage] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704214349/http://whc.unesco.org/archive/convention-en.pdf |date=4 July 2010 }} which was adopted by the General Conference of [[UNESCO]] on 16 November 1972. Since then, 193 state parties have ratified the convention, making it one of the most widely recognized international agreements and the world's most popular cultural program. As of July 2018, a total of 1,092 World Heritage sites (845 cultural, 209 natural, and 38 mixed properties) exist across [[Table of World Heritage Sites by country|167 countries]]. [[List of World Heritage Sites in Italy|Italy]], with 54 sites, has the most of any country, followed by [[List of World Heritage Sites in China|China]] (53), [[List of World Heritage Sites in Spain|Spain]] (47), [[List of World Heritage Sites in France|France]] (44), [[List of World Heritage Sites in Germany|Germany]] (44), [[List of World Heritage Sites in India|India]] (37), and [[List of World Heritage Sites in Mexico|Mexico]] (35).{{Cite web|url=https:/whc.unesco.org/en/list|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre - World Heritage List|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-03}} ==History== {{See also|World Heritage Committee}} {{Infobox treaty | name = Convention concerning the Protection of the World's Cultural and Natural Heritage | long_name = | image = | image_width = | caption = | type = | date_drafted = | date_signed = 16 November 1972 | location_signed = Paris, France | date_sealed = | date_effective = 17 December 1975 | condition_effective = 20 ratifications | date_expiration = | signatories = | parties = | ratifiers = 193 (189 [[UN member states]] plus the [[Cook Islands]], the [[Holy See]], [[Niue]], and [[State of Palestine|Palestine]]) | depositor = Director-General of the [[United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] | language = | languages = Arabic, English, French, Russian, and Spanish | wikisource = }} In 1954, the government of [[Egypt]] decided to build the new [[Aswan Dam|Aswan High Dam]], whose resulting future reservoir would eventually [[Flood|inundate]] a large stretch of the [[Nile]] valley containing cultural treasures of [[ancient Egypt]] and ancient [[Nubia]]. In 1959, the governments of Egypt and [[Sudan]] requested UNESCO to assist their countries to protect and rescue the endangered monuments and sites. In 1960, the Director-General of UNESCO launched an appeal to the member states for an International Campaign to Save the Monuments of Nubia.[http://whc.unesco.org/en/activities/172/ Monuments of Nubia-International Campaign to Save the Monuments of Nubia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429024818/http://whc.unesco.org/en/activities/172 |date=29 April 2009 }} World Heritage Convention, UNESCO This appeal resulted in the excavation and recording of hundreds of sites, the recovery of thousands of objects, as well as the salvage and relocation to higher ground of a number of important temples, the most famous of which are the temple complexes of [[Abu Simbel temples|Abu Simbel]] and [[Philae]]. The campaign, which ended in 1980, was considered a success. As tokens of its gratitude to countries which especially contributed to the campaign's success, Egypt donated four temples: the [[Temple of Dendur]] was moved to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York City, the [[Temple of Debod]] was moved to the [[Parque del Oeste]] in Madrid, the [[Temple of Taffeh]] was moved to the [[Rijksmuseum van Oudheden]] in the Netherlands, and the [[Temple of Ellesyia]] to [[Museo Egizio]] in Turin.[http://whc.unesco.org/en/activities/173/ The Rescue of Nubian Monuments and Sites] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150227222650/http://whc.unesco.org/en/activities/173/ |date=27 February 2015 }}, UNESCO The project cost $80 million, about $40 million of which was collected from 50 countries.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} The project's success led to other safeguarding campaigns: saving [[Venice]] and its [[Venetian Lagoon|lagoon]] in Italy, the ruins of [[Mohenjo-daro]] in Pakistan, and the [[Borobodur]] Temple Compounds in Indonesia. UNESCO then initiated, with the [[International Council on Monuments and Sites]], a draft convention to protect the common cultural heritage of humanity. {{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} ===Convention and background=== The United States initiated the idea of cultural conservation with nature conservation. The [[White House]] conference in 1965 called for a "World Heritage Trust" to preserve "the world's superb natural and scenic areas and historic sites for the present and the future of the entire world citizenry". The [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]] developed similar proposals in 1968, and they were presented in 1972 to the [[United Nations Conference on the Human Environment]] in [[Stockholm]]. Under the World Heritage Committee, signatory countries are required to produce and submit periodic [[data reporting]] providing the World Heritage Committee with an overview of each participating nation's implementation of the World Heritage Convention and a "snapshot" of current conditions at World Heritage properties. A single text was agreed on by all parties, and the "Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage" was adopted by the General Conference of UNESCO on 16 November 1972. The Convention came into force on 17 December 1975. As of May 2017, it has been ratified by 193 states parties,{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/|author=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|title=States Parties – UNESCO World Heritage Centre|website=whc.unesco.org|accessdate=18 March 2018}} including 189 [[UN member states]] plus the [[Cook Islands]], the [[Holy See]], [[Niue]], and the [[State of Palestine]]. Only four UN member states have not ratified the Convention: Liechtenstein, Nauru, Somalia and Tuvalu.[http://www.unesco.org/eri/la/convention.asp?KO=13055&language=E Convention concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage: Treaty status] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719235637/http://www.unesco.org/eri/la/convention.asp?KO=13055&language=E |date=19 July 2013 }}. ==Nominating process== A country must first list its significant cultural and natural sites; the result is called the Tentative List. A country may not nominate sites that have not been first included on the Tentative List. Next, it can place sites selected from that list into a Nomination File. The Nomination File is evaluated by the [[International Council on Monuments and Sites]] and the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature|World Conservation Union]]. These bodies then make their recommendations to the World Heritage Committee. The Committee meets once per year to determine whether or not to inscribe each nominated property on the World Heritage List and sometimes defers or refers the decision to request more information from the country which nominated the site. There are ten selection criteria – a site must meet at least one of them to be included on the list.{{cite web | url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/guidelines/ | title=The Operational Guidelines for the Implementation of the World Heritage Convention | publisher=UNESCO | accessdate=10 July 2017 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170714073431/http://whc.unesco.org/en/guidelines/ | archivedate=14 July 2017 | df=dmy-all }} ==Selection criteria== Up to 2004, there were six criteria for cultural heritage and four criteria for natural heritage. In 2005, this was modified so that there is now only one set of ten criteria. Nominated sites must be of "outstanding universal value" and meet at least one of the ten criteria.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|title=Criteria for Selection|publisher=World Heritage|accessdate=14 October 2006|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160612152223/http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|archivedate=12 June 2016|df=dmy-all}} These criteria have been modified or/amended several times since their creation. ===Cultural criteria=== [[File:Taj Mahal 2012.jpg|thumb|Site#252: [[Taj Mahal]], an example of a cultural heritage site.|alt=Site#252: The Taj Mahal, an example of a world heritage site.]]
  1. "represents a masterpiece of human creative genius and cultural significance"
  2. "exhibits an important interchange of human values, over a span of time, or within a cultural area of the world, on developments in architecture or technology, monumental arts, town-planning, or landscape design"
  3. "to bear a unique or at least exceptional testimony to a cultural tradition or to a civilization which is living or which has disappeared"
  4. "is an outstanding example of a type of building, architectural, or technological ensemble or landscape which illustrates a significant stage in human history"
  5. "is an outstanding example of a traditional human settlement, land-use, or sea-use which is representative of a culture, or human interaction with the environment especially when it has become vulnerable under the impact of irreversible change"
  6. "is directly or tangibly associated with events or living traditions, with ideas, or with beliefs, with artistic and literary works of outstanding universal significance"
    7. {{cite web|title=UNESCO World Heritage, The Criteria for Selection|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160612152223/http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|archivedate=12 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}
===Natural criteria=== [[File:Zerbras drinking.jpg|upright=1.15|thumb|Site#156: [[Serengeti National Park]], an example of a natural heritage site.]] [[File:80 - Machu Picchu - Juin 2009 - edit.2.jpg|upright=1.15|thumb|Site#274: [[Machu Picchu|Historic Sanctuary of Machu Picchu]], an example of a mixed heritage site.]]
  1. "contains superlative natural phenomena or areas of exceptional natural beauty and aesthetic importance"
  2. "is an outstanding example representing major stages of Earth's history, including the record of life, significant on-going geological processes in the development of landforms, or significant geomorphic or physiographic features"
  3. "is an outstanding example representing significant on-going ecological and biological processes in the evolution and development of terrestrial, fresh water, coastal and marine ecosystems, and communities of plants and animals"
  4. "contains the most important and significant natural habitats for in-situ conservation of biological diversity, including those containing threatened species of outstanding universal value from the point of view of science or conservation"
===Legal status of designated sites=== UNESCO designation as a World Heritage site provides ''[[prima facie]]'' evidence that such culturally sensitive sites are legally protected pursuant to the Law of War, under the [[Geneva Convention]], its articles, protocols and customs, together with other treaties including the [[Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict]] and international law. Thus, the Geneva Convention treaty promulgates: "Article 53. PROTECTION OF CULTURAL OBJECTS AND OF PLACES OF WORSHIP. Without prejudice to the provisions of the Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict of 14 May 1954,' and of other relevant international instruments, it is prohibited:{{cite web |author=UN General Assembly |authorlink=United Nations General Assembly |date=1979 |origyear=8 June 1977 |title=UN Treaty No. 17512 |series=Treaty Series |url=http://treaties.un.org/doc/Publication/UNTS/Volume%201125/volume-1125-I-17512-English.pdf |format=PDF |work='Volume 1125-1' UN |page=27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309204240/http://treaties.un.org/doc/Publication/UNTS/Volume%201125/volume-1125-I-17512-English.pdf |archivedate=9 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}
:(a) To commit any acts of hostility directed against the historic monuments, works of art or places of worship which constitute the cultural or spiritual heritage of peoples; :(b) To use such objects in support of the military effort; :(c) To make such objects the object of reprisals." ==Extensions and other modifications== A country may request to extend or reduce the boundaries, modify the official name, or change the selection criteria of one of its already listed sites. Any proposal for a significant boundary change or modify the site's selection criteria must be submitted as if it were a new nomination, including first placing it on the Tentative List and then onto the Nomination File. A request for a minor boundary change, one that does not have a significantly impact on the extent of the property or affect its "outstanding universal value", is also evaluated by the advisory bodies before being sent to the Committee. Such proposals can be rejected by either the advisory bodies or the Committee if they judge it to be a significant change instead of a minor one. Proposals to change the site's official name is sent directly to the Committee. ==Endangered sites== {{main|List of World Heritage in Danger|Former UNESCO World Heritage sites}} A site may be added to the [[List of World Heritage in Danger]] if there are conditions that threaten the characteristics for which the landmark or area was inscribed on the World Heritage List. Such problems may involve armed conflict and war, natural disasters, pollution, poaching, or uncontrolled urbanization or human development. This danger list is intended to increase international awareness of the threats and to encourage counteractive measures. Threats to a site can be either proven imminent threats or potential dangers that could have adverse effects on a site.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/158/|title=List of World Heritage in Danger|publisher=UNESCO|accessdate=10 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150321040701/http://whc.unesco.org/en/158/|archivedate=21 March 2015|df=dmy-all}} The state of conservation for each site on the danger list is reviewed on a yearly basis, after which the committee may request additional measures, delete the property from the list if the threats have ceased or consider deletion from both the List of World Heritage in Danger and the World Heritage List. Only two sites have ever been [[Former UNESCO World Heritage sites|delisted]]: the [[Arabian Oryx Sanctuary]] in Oman and the [[Dresden Elbe Valley]] in Germany. The Arabian Oryx Sanctuary was directly delisted in 2007, instead of first being put on the danger list, after the Omani government decided to reduce the protected area's size by 90 percent.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/362|title=Oman's Arabian Oryx Sanctuary: first site ever to be deleted from UNESCO's World Heritage List|publisher=UNESCO|accessdate=10 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118001455/http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/362|archivedate=18 January 2008|df=dmy-all}} The Dresden Elbe Valley was first placed on the danger list in 2006 when the World Heritage Committee decided that plans to construct the [[Waldschlösschen Bridge]] would significantly alter the valley's landscape. In response, the Dresden City Council attempted to stop the bridge's construction, but after several court decisions allowed the building of the bridge to proceed, the valley was removed from the World Heritage List in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/522|title=Dresden is deleted from UNESCO’s World Heritage List|publisher=UNESCO|accessdate=10 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170707003437/http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/522/|archivedate=7 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} The first global assessment to quantitatively measure [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0006320716310138 threats to Natural World Heritage sites] found that 63 percent of sites have been damaged by increasing [https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms12558 human pressures] including encroaching roads, agriculture infrastructure and settlements over the last two decades. These activities endanger Natural World Heritage sites and could compromise their unique values. Of the Natural World Heritage sites that contain forest, 91 percent of those experienced some loss since the year 2000. Many Natural World Heritage sites are more threatened than previously thought and require immediate conservation action. ==Statistics== [[File:Unesco_world_heritage_sites.png|upright=2.25|right|thumb|

]] {{See also|World Heritage sites by country|Lists of World Heritage sites|List of World Heritage in Danger|List of World Heritage sites by year of inscription}} There are 1092 World Heritage sites located in 167 states. Of these, 845 are cultural, 209 are natural and 38 are mixed properties. The World Heritage Committee has divided the world into five geographic zones which it calls regions: Africa, Arab states, Asia and the Pacific, Europe and North America, and Latin America and the Caribbean. Russia and the [[Caucasus]] states are classified as European, while Mexico and the Caribbean are classified as belonging to the Latin America & Caribbean zone, despite their location in North America. The UNESCO geographic zones also give greater emphasis on administrative, rather than geographic associations. Hence, [[Gough Island]], located in the South Atlantic, is part of the Europe & North America region because the government of the United Kingdom nominated the site. ==Consequences== Despite the successes of World Heritage listing in promoting conservation, the UNESCO administered project has attracted criticism from some for perceived under-representation of heritage sites outside Europe, disputed decisions on site selection and adverse impact of mass tourism on sites unable to manage rapid growth in visitor numbers.{{cite news|last1=Barron|first1=Laignee|title='Unesco-cide': does world heritage status do cities more harm than good?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2017/aug/30/unescocide-world-heritage-status-hurt-help-tourism|accessdate=3 September 2017|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=30 August 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Vallely|first1=Paul|title=The Big Question: What is a World Heritage Site, and does the accolade make a difference?|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/the-big-question-what-is-a-world-heritage-site-and-does-the-accolade-make-a-difference-997955.html|work=The Independent|date=7 November 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027192333/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/the-big-question-what-is-a-world-heritage-site-and-does-the-accolade-make-a-difference-997955.html|archivedate=27 October 2016|df=dmy-all}} A sizable [[Lobbying|lobbying industry]] has grown around the awards because World Heritage listing has the potential to significantly increase tourism revenue from sites selected. Site listing bids are often lengthy and costly, putting poorer countries at a disadvantage. Eritrea's efforts to promote [[Asmara]] are one example.{{cite news|title=Modernist masterpieces in unlikely Asmara|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/prospero/2016/07/architecture-eritrea?zid=317|work=The Economist|date=20 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170715102559/https://www.economist.com/blogs/prospero/2016/07/architecture-eritrea?zid=317|archivedate=15 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} In 2016, the Australian government was reported to have successfully lobbied for [[Great Barrier Reef]] conservation efforts to be removed from a UNESCO report titled 'World Heritage and Tourism in a Changing Climate'. The Australian government's actions were in response to their concern about the negative impact that an 'at risk' label could have on tourism revenue at a previously designated UNESCO World Heritage site.{{cite news|last1=Slezak|first1=Michael|title=Australia scrubbed from UN climate change report after government intervention|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/27/australia-scrubbed-from-un-climate-change-report-after-government-intervention|work=The Guardian|date=26 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027130133/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/27/australia-scrubbed-from-un-climate-change-report-after-government-intervention|archivedate=27 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|last1=Hasham|first1=Nicole|title=Government spent at least $400,000 lobbying against Great Barrier Reef 'danger' listing|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/government-spent-at-least-400000-lobbying-against-great-barrier-reef-danger-listing-20150914-gjlwr2.html|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=17 September 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161228235450/http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/government-spent-at-least-400000-lobbying-against-great-barrier-reef-danger-listing-20150914-gjlwr2.html|archivedate=28 December 2016|df=dmy-all}} A number of listed World Heritage locations such as [[George Town, Penang]], and [[Casco Viejo, Panama]], have struggled to strike the balance between the economic benefits of catering to greatly increased visitor numbers and preserving the original culture and local communities that drew the recognition.{{cite news|last1=Maurel|first1=Cholé|title=The unintended {{Coord|56.59054|N|9.64147|E|display=title}} [[File:Viborg Kommune - Klejtrup - Verdenskortet 06 ies.jpg|thumb|300px|Europe and Africa]] The '''World Map at Lake Klejtrup''' ({{lang-da|Verdenskortet ved Klejtrup Sø}}) is a miniature [[world map]] built of stones and grass in [[Klejtrup Sø]] near the village of [[Klejtrup]], [[Viborg Municipality]], [[Denmark]].
In 1943, Søren Poulsen, a local farmer, was working on the drainage of the surrounding meadows when he found a stone shaped like the [[Jutland]] peninsula. This inspired him to create a small world of his own.<ref name=amazing>{{cite web |url=http://www.amusingplanet.com/2015/11/the-world-map-at-lake-klejtrup.html |title=The World Map at Lake Klejtrup |accessdate=September 9, 2016 |date=November 21, 2015 |format= |work=Amusing Planet }}</ref> During the winter months, with the use of primitive tools, he placed big stones carefully on the ice. When spring arrived, the stones could easily be tilted into place, and in this way the World Map took shape. Some of the stones used weighted more than 2 tonnes.<ref name=ripley>{{cite web |url=http://www.ripleys.com/blog/world-map/ |title=Man Builds Entire World Map in His Back Yard |accessdate=September 9, 2016 |date=December 2, 2015 |format= |work=Ripley's Believe it or Not |publisher=Ripley Entertainment }}</ref>
Poulsen created the World Map between 1944 and 1969. It measures 45 by 90 metres (49 by 98 yards), covering an area of over 4000 square meters (1 acre).<ref name=amazing /> <ref name=bigthink>{{cite web |url=http://bigthink.com/strange-maps/a-very-danish-map-of-the-world |title=A Very Danish Map of the World |accessdate=September 9, 2016 |last=Jacobs |first=Frank |work=Big Think |publisher=The Big Think Inc. }}</ref> One 111-kilometre (69 mi) [[Degree (angle)|degree]] of [[latitude]] corresponds to 27 centimetres (11 [[inch|inches]]) on the map.<ref name=amazing /> <ref name=bigthink /> On Poulsen's map, [[Antarctica]] is not present and the [[Northern Hemisphere]] is marked in two places, ensuring a better impression of the correct distances between the countries to avoid the difficulties of spreading out our planet's globular shape.<ref name=bigthink /> Red poles mark the [[equator]], and each country is represented by miniature flags, <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thevintagenews.com/2016/09/02/priority-world-map-lake-klejtrup-danish-farmer-spent-last-25-years-life-built-version-world/ |title=The World Map at Lake Klejtrup: A Danish farmer spent the last 25 years of his life building his own miniature version of the world |accessdate=September 9, 2016 |publisher=The Vintage News }}</ref> <ref name=ripley /> which are updated yearly.<ref name=bigthink /> State borders in the [[United States of America]] are marked with yellow bricks; Poulsen lived 20 years in America.<ref name=bigthink />
The map is the epicenter of a park, which has, among other attractions, a [[picnic]] area, a coffee shop and a playground.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.visitviborg.com/ln-int/verdenskortet-ved-klejtrup-so-gdk601190 |title=Verdenskortet ved Klejtrup Sø |accessdate=September 9, 2016 |work=Visit Viborg }}</ref>
The World Map is an important attraction in the area,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.atlasobscura.com/places/verdenskortet |title=Verdenskortet |accessdate=September 9, 2016 |publisher=Atlas Obscura }}</ref> and attracts about 40,000 visitors per year, most of them Danish.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pure.au.dk/portal-asb-student/files/74993761/Markedsf_ringsstrategi_for_Verdenskortet_v_Klejtrup_S_.pdf |title=Markedsføringsstrategi for Verdenskortet v/Klejtrup sø |accessdate=September 9, 2016 |last=Olsen |first=Sara Janner |date=May 2014 |format=PDF |publisher=[[Aarhus University]] |location=[[Aarhus]] |language=Danish }}</ref>
